377, 6-18-2018)
15-1-13: ONE-WAY STREETS AND ALLEYS:
Wherever authorized "one-way" street or alley signs have been erected on any
street or alley, it shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to proceed
along such street or alley in a direction otherwise than indicated by such
signs.
   A.   The following are hereby determined to be and are established as one-
way streets:
      1.   North Boulevard from Cuyler Avenue to Ridgeland Avenue, one- way
westbound.
      2.   Superior Street from Maple Avenue to Harlem Avenue, one-way
westbound.
      3.   Maple Avenue from a point one hundred twenty feet (120') south of
Chicago Avenue to Superior Street, one-way northbound.
      4.   North Boulevard from a point sixty feet (60') east of Humphrey
Avenue to Austin Boulevard, one-way eastbound.
      5.   Forest Avenue from LeMoyne Parkway to North Avenue, one-way
northbound.
      6.   Elmwood Avenue between Lake Street and Ontario Street is hereby
determined to be and is a one-way southbound street on Saturdays from seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. to two o'clock (2:00) P.M. from the first Saturday in June
to the last Saturday in October.
      7.   Clarence Avenue between Harrison Street and Van Buren Street, one-
way eastbound.
      8.   North Boulevard between Oak Park Avenue and Euclid Avenue, one-way
eastbound.
      9.   Ontario Street between Oak Park Avenue and Kenilworth Avenue, one-
way westbound.
      10.   Grove Avenue between Harvard Street and Fillmore Street, one- way
southbound.
      11.   Scoville Avenue between Erie Street and a point two hundred twenty
five feet (225') north of Lake Street, one-way southbound.
      12.   Flournoy Street between Taylor and Humphrey Avenues, one-way
westbound.
      13.   Cuyler Avenue between Harvard and Fillmore Streets, one-way
southbound.
      14.   Highland Avenue from Jackson Boulevard to Van Buren Street, one-way
southbound.
      15.   Harvey Avenue from Thomas Street to Augusta Street, one-way
southbound.
      16.   North Boulevard from Forest Avenue to Oak Park Avenue, one-way
eastbound.
      17.   South Boulevard from Oak Park Avenue to Home Avenue, one-way
westbound.
      18.   North Boulevard from Marion Street to Forest Avenue, one-way
eastbound.
      19.   Euclid Avenue between North Avenue and a point one hundred twenty
five feet (125') south of North Avenue, one-way northbound.
   B.   The following are hereby determined to be and are established as one-
way alleys:
      1.   North-south alley east of Forest Avenue between Division Street and
Berkshire Street, one-way southbound.
      2.   The two (2) east-west alleys intersecting with Austin Boulevard
between South Boulevard and Washington Boulevard, one- way eastbound.
      3.   East-west alley east of Oak Park Avenue located midblock between
Lake Street and North Boulevard, one-way westbound.
      4.   The east-west alley located south of North Avenue between Marion
Street and Belleforte Avenue, one-way westbound.
      5.   The north-south alley located north of Berkshire Street and south of
Lenox Street between Elmwood Avenue and Ridgeland Avenue, one-way southbound.
      6.   The north-south alley located between Cuyler Avenue and Harvey
Avenue from the east-west alley immediately north of and parallel to Madison
Street to the east-west alley immediately south of and parallel to Washington
Boulevard, one-way southbound.
      7.   The east-west alley located immediately north of and parallel to
Washington Boulevard between Scoville Avenue and the north- south alley
immediately west of and parallel to Scoville Avenue, one-way eastbound.
      8.   The east-west alley located immediately north of and parallel to
Madison Street between Cuyler Avenue and Ridgeland Avenue, one-way westbound.
      9.   The east-west alley located immediately south of and parallel to
Madison Street between Wisconsin Avenue and Wenonah Avenue, one-way eastbound.
      10.   The north-south alley located immediately west of Forest Avenue
between Erie Street and Ontario Street, one-way northbound.
      11.   The east-west alley located immediately south of Garfield Street
between Austin Boulevard and the north-south alley immediately west of Austin
Boulevard, one-way eastbound. (Ord. 2014-0-06, 2-3-2014)
15-1-14: PROHIBITED TURN LOCATIONS:
   A.   Left turns are prohibited at the following locations:
      1.   Westbound traffic exiting onto Oak Park Avenue from east-west alley
lying midblock between and parallel to North Boulevard and Lake Street.
      2.   Northbound or southbound traffic on Austin Boulevard at the
intersection of South Boulevard from four o'clock (4:00) P.M. to six o'clock
(6:00) P.M. only, except Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.
      3.   Westbound traffic on North Boulevard at Ridgeland Avenue.
      4.   Westbound traffic exiting onto Humphrey Avenue from the east- west
alley lying south of and parallel to South Boulevard.
      5.   Southbound traffic on Harlem Avenue at South Boulevard.
      6.   Westbound traffic on Westgate at Harlem Avenue.
      7.   Northbound and southbound traffic on Grove Avenue at Jackson
Boulevard.
      8.   Northbound traffic on Harlem Avenue at Jackson Boulevard from seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and from four o'clock (4:00)
P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M. only.
      9.   Northbound Austin Boulevard onto westbound Greenfield Street.
      10.   From northbound Oak Park Avenue onto westbound LeMoyne Street
between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and
four o'clock (4:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M. Monday through Friday.
      11.   From southbound Oak Park Avenue onto eastbound Superior Street
between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and
four o'clock (4:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M. Monday through Friday.
      12.   Southbound traffic on Oak Park Avenue at Randolph Street.
      13.   Westbound traffic on Randolph Street at Oak Park Avenue.
      14.   Southbound traffic on Harlem Avenue at Westgate Street.
      15.   Northbound traffic on Maple Avenue at Lake Street.
   B.   Right turns only are permitted at the following locations:
      1.   For eastbound traffic on Superior Street at Austin Boulevard.
      2.   For westbound traffic on LeMoyne Street onto Oak Park Avenue.
      3.   For northbound traffic on Humphrey Avenue at Division Street.
      4.   For northbound traffic on Taylor Avenue at Division Street.
      5.   For eastbound traffic on Harvard Street at Austin Boulevard.
      6.   For southbound traffic on Forest Avenue at Ontario Street.
      7.   For eastbound traffic on Greenfield Street at Ridgeland Avenue.
      8.   For eastbound traffic exiting onto Ridgeland Avenue from the
Northridge Shopping Center driveway located on the west side of Ridgeland
Avenue approximately twenty feet (20') south of North Avenue.
      9.   For westbound traffic on North Boulevard at Harlem Avenue.
      10.   For westbound traffic exiting onto Rossell Avenue from the parking
lot located on the southeast corner of Rossell Avenue and North Avenue.
      11.   For southbound traffic on Euclid Avenue at Washington Boulevard.
      12.   For northbound and southbound traffic on Kenilworth Avenue at
Washington Boulevard.
      13.   For eastbound traffic on Randolph Street at Oak Park Avenue.
      14.   For northbound traffic on Scoville Avenue at Washington Boulevard
between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and
two o'clock (2:00) P.M. to four o'clock (4:00) P.M. Monday through Friday.
      15.   For westbound traffic exiting onto Ridgeland Avenue from the east-
west alley lying immediately north of and parallel to Madison Street.
      16.   For eastbound traffic exiting onto Euclid Avenue from the CVS
Pharmacy driveway located on the west side of Euclid Avenue approximately
eighty five feet (85') north of Roosevelt Road.
      17.   For westbound traffic exiting onto Oak Park Avenue from the CVS
Pharmacy driveway located on the east side of Oak Park Avenue approximately one
hundred feet (100') north of Roosevelt Road.
   C.   No turns are permitted at the following locations:
      1.   For northbound and southbound traffic on Austin Boulevard into
Superior Street in Oak Park.
      2.   For northbound and southbound traffic on Austin Boulevard into
Harvard Street in Oak Park.
      3.   For northbound and southbound traffic on Ridgeland Avenue into North
Boulevard.
   D.   Right turns are prohibited at the following locations:
      1.   For traffic exiting from the parking lot located at the northwest
corner of Austin Boulevard and Jackson Boulevard into the north-south alley
adjacent to said lot.
      2.   For traffic exiting from the parking lot adjacent to Fair Oaks
Pharmacy, 400 Chicago Avenue, into the north-south alley adjacent to the
parking lot.
      3.   For southbound traffic on Humphrey Avenue at Ontario Street.
      4.   For eastbound traffic on Division Street at Elmwood Avenue between
the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and four
o'clock (4:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M. Monday through Friday.
      5.   For eastbound traffic on North Avenue at Grove Avenue between the
hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and four o'clock
(4:00) P.M. to six o'clock (6:00) P.M. Monday through Friday.
   E.   All traffic is prohibited:
      1.   From proceeding on Maple Avenue in a southbound direction past the
barrier peninsula traffic diverter located approximately two hundred fifty feet
(250') south of Monroe Street. (Ord. 17-305, 11-20-2017)

   A.   Right turns are prohibited at all times on a red light at the following
intersections:
      1.   Ridgeland Avenue and Division Street.
      2.   Forest Avenue and Lake Street.
      3.   South Boulevard and Austin Boulevard.
      4.   South Boulevard and Oak Park Avenue.
      5.   Oak Park Avenue and Harrison Street.
      6.   Oak Park Avenue and Garfield Street.
      7.   Washington Boulevard and Ridgeland Avenue.
      8.   Marion Street and Lake Street.
   B.   Right turns are prohibited on a red light at the following
intersections from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) P.M.
except as noted:
      1.   Ridgeland Avenue and Lake Street.
      2.   Oak Park Avenue and Lake Street.
      3.   Madison Street and Ridgeland Avenue.
      4.   Madison Street and Oak Park Avenue.
      5.   Washington Boulevard and Oak Park Avenue.
      6.   Jackson Boulevard and Ridgeland Avenue.
      7.   Harvard Street and Ridgeland Avenue.
      8.   For northbound traffic on Ridgeland Avenue at Augusta Street when
children are present.
      9.   Jackson Boulevard and Highland Avenue when children are present.
      10.   South Boulevard and Ridgeland Avenue. (Ord. 2009-0-035, 6-1-2009;
amd. Ord. 21-62, 10-4-2021)
15-1-16: LIMITED AND PROHIBITED PARKING; PARKING ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to park in a
prohibited parking zone.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to park in a limited parking zone longer than the
time designated by authorized signs.
   C.   It shall be unlawful to park on private property without the consent of
the owner of the private property or to park in any parking lot which is not
licensed, as provided in chapter 8 of this code. (Ord. 1997-0-13, 3-17-1997)
15-1-17: NIGHT PARKING; RESTRICTED HOURS:
In order to facilitate police protection, street cleaning, leaf and snow
removal, it shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to park said
vehicle, or for the owner of said vehicle to permit said vehicle to be parked,
on any street in the Village between the hours of two thirty o'clock (2:30)
A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of any day, except for emergency vehicles, and
except where vehicles having permits are parked in authorized parking enclaves
established pursuant to this chapter and identified below.
Any lease and application for lease of residential property in the Village
shall contain a clause advising the tenant of the Village overnight parking
restriction, and that the lessee is responsible for providing off street
parking for the lessee's vehicle during those hours specified above to the
extent such parking is not provided by the lessor. Any lease not containing the
foregoing language shall be voidable by the lessee.
Authorized Parking Bays:
   A.   Twenty one (21) metered parking spaces located in the bay on the north
side of South Boulevard and lying between Ridgeland Avenue and Cuyler Avenue.
   B.   All spaces in the bay located on the north side of South Boulevard
immediately to the west of Austin Boulevard.
   C.   All spaces in the bay located on the north side of South Boulevard
between Ridgeland Avenue and Elmwood Avenue.
   D.   All spaces in the several bays located on the following named east-west
streets immediately to the west of and separated by parkway from Austin
Boulevard:
      1.   Fillmore Street.
      2.   Van Buren Street.
      3.   Adams Street.
      4.   Randolph Street.
      5.   Pleasant Street. (Ord. 1983-0-22, 4-4-1983)
   E.   Fifteen (15) parking spaces located on the south side of North
Boulevard west of East Avenue adjacent to the Chicago Northwestern Railroad
embankment. (Ord. 1983-0-70, 10-3-1983)
15-1-18: PARKING IN ALLEY:
It shall be unlawful for any driver to park a vehicle within an alley in such a
manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than eight feet (8')
of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic; and
there shall be no parking in any alley for a time longer than is necessary to
load or unload passengers or materials. (1981 Code)
15-1-19: MISCELLANEOUS PARKING OFFENSES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to park or for the owner of a motor vehicle
to permit it to be parked as follows:
   A.   Blocking a driveway.
   B.   On or across a sidewalk.
   C.   In an intersection or crosswalk.
   D.   In a viaduct.
   E.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
   F.   In a bus stop, loading zone or cabstand.
   G.   Under a fire escape.
   H.   The wrong way on a one-way street.
   I.   On any two-way street so that the driver's side of the car is nearest
to the curb.
   J.   Backed into a stall in a Municipal parking lot.
   K.   More than twelve inches (12") from the curb.
   L.   In any private parking lot not licensed as provided in Chapter 8 of
this Code. Signs shall be posted by the Village on the parkway at the entrance
of any such lot reading as follows:
   No Parking In This Lot
   Police Order
   M.   No truck or commercial vehicle bearing a Class C or heavier State of
Illinois "license plate" as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-815,
or having a gross weight capacity (including vehicle and maximum load) in
excess of eight thousand (8,000) pounds, shall be parked on a public street or
a public or private driveway in any residence district as defined by the Zoning
Ordinance, except when making deliveries or to perform requested service at a
particular residence.
   N.   Tourist buses for the Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio or other
historic buildings on Forest Avenue shall be parked only in a designated bus
stand on Chicago Avenue adjacent to Holmes School playground. While so parked
the motor of the bus shall be turned off so as to reduce noise and exhaust
fumes.
   O.   Double parked.
   P.   In an area restricted to the loading and unloading of children.
   Q.   When any bus is parked or standing longer than fifteen (15) minutes,
its engine shall be turned off so as to reduce noise and exhaust fumes. (1981
Code)
15-1-20: COMMERCIAL ACTIVITIES FROM PARKED VEHICLE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle:
   A.   On a street, parkway or Village controlled parking lot for the purpose
of repairing said vehicle, provided that emergency repairs on a disabled
vehicle are permitted; or
   B.   On a street, parkway, alley or Village controlled parking lot for the
commercial purpose of selling or displaying a motor vehicle, or the sale of any
item from a motor vehicle, provided that on-street commercial activities
conducted pursuant to any licensed business activity as described in Chapter 8
of this Code is permitted. (Ord. 1982-0-67, 12-6-82)
15-1-21: CAB OUTSIDE OF STAND:
It shall be unlawful to park any cab outside a designated cabstand for the
purpose of waiting for the potential pick up of unsummoned-for fares. (1981
Code)
15-1-22: EMERGENCY SNOW PARKING:
The following restrictions are adopted in order to facilitate snow removal and
the movement of traffic under winter conditions:
   A.   At such times as there is an accumulation of two inches (2") of snow on
the streets in the Village, it shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle
to park said vehicle, or for the owner of any vehicle to permit said vehicle to
be parked, on the even side (as indicated by address) on odd days (as indicated
by date) or on the odd side (as indicated by address) on even days (as
indicated by date) of any such street in the Village between the hours of eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. except for emergency vehicles,
vehicles making deliveries which do not exceed ten (10) minutes, and except for
the streets as identified in subsections B and D of this Section.
   B.   At such times as there is an accumulation of two inches (2") of snow on
the streets in the Village, it shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle
to park said vehicle, or for the owner of any vehicle to permit said vehicle to
be parked, on any emergency snow routes designated on the map contained in
section
15-1-23 of this article, except for emergency vehicles and vehicles making
deliveries which do not exceed ten (10) minutes.
   C.   The amount of accumulation of snow shall be determined by the enforcing
officer in a manner that reflects the depth of snow at locations near the
parked vehicle.
   D.   At such times as there is an accumulation of two inches (2") of snow on
the streets in the Village, it shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle,
or for the owner of any vehicle to be parked, on the even side (as indicated by
address) on odd days (as indicated by date) or on the odd side (as indicated by
address) on even days (as indicated by date) of the following streets in the
Village between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:
00) A.M. except for emergency vehicles and vehicles making deliveries which do
not exceed ten (10) minutes:
      1.   The west side of Marion Street, from Superior Street to Chicago
Avenue.
      2.   The north side of Westgate Street, Harlem Avenue to 1126 Westgate
Street.
      3.   Marion Street, from Lake Street to Ontario Street.
      4.   North Boulevard, from Euclid Avenue to Kenilworth Avenue.
      5.   South Boulevard, from Euclid Avenue to Kenilworth Avenue.
      6.   Marion Street, from South Boulevard to Pleasant Street.
      7.   South Boulevard, from Forest Avenue to Maple Avenue.
      8.   Pleasant Street, from Marion Street to Maple Avenue.
      9.   The west side of Maple Avenue, from Garfield Street to Lexington
Avenue.
      10.   The north side of Harrison Street, from Oak Park Avenue to Grove
Avenue.
   E.   The provisions of this section shall override all other Village parking
regulations, including all permit parking regulations of the Village.
   F.   Vehicles violating any of the provisions of this section may be towed
without prior notice. (Ord. 1999-0-41, 9-7-99)
15-1-23: SNOW ROUTE MAP:
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/939533cf0e4682a2aa68b2d78fc3bca5e1eb689b/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3318.gif]
(Ord. 1999-0-41, 9-7-99)
15-1-24: RESERVED PARKING AND DROP OFF ZONES FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES:
   A.   Reserved Parking For Persons With Disabilities:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person, except a person with a
disability or a person transporting a person with a disability, to park a motor
vehicle in any public parking area posted Reserved Parking and bearing the
international symbol indicating parking reserved for persons with disabilities.
For the purposes of this section, "a person with a disability" shall mean a
person with registration plates or a decal or device designated for a person
with a disability pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-616, 5/11-
1301.1, 5/11-1301.2, or to veterans with disabilities as provided in 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-609. The decal or device must be displayed on
the vehicle parked in the designated area.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any individual who is not the authorized
holder of the disability license plate or parking decal or device and who is
not transporting the authorized holder of the disability license plate or
parking decal or device to and from the parking location to use the disability
license plate or parking decal or device to exercise any privileges granted by
or through the disability license plate or parking decal or device.
      3.   Upon request of a person with a disability who has been issued
registration plates pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-616 or a
decal issued pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1301.2, a parking
space shall be reserved in the street adjacent to the residence of the person
with a disability and so designated by an official sign of the Department of
Public Works. No person shall park a motor vehicle in the space so designated
unless it bears special registration plates issued pursuant to 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3-616 or a decal issued pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-1301.2.
   B.   Drop Off Zones For Persons With Disabilities: It shall be unlawful for
any person to park a motor vehicle or stop a motor vehicle for the purpose of
loading or unloading persons or things, other than persons with disabilities,
in any public parking area posted as a drop off zone for persons with
disabilities.
Drop off zones for persons with disabilities shall meet the following criteria:
      1.   The person or entity seeking the drop off zone for persons with
disabilities must demonstrate the need for such a zone. Factors to be
considered in determining the need for such a drop off zone shall include the
following: the number of persons with disabilities traveling to and from the
proposed drop off zone location, the frequency of this activity, the
difficulties encountered without the proposed drop off zone and the alternate
solutions available.
      2.   The proposed drop off zone for persons with disabilities shall not
have a substantial negative impact on existing parking and traffic conditions
in the area.
      3.   The need which must be demonstrated under this subsection
15-1-24B must not be the need for parking for persons with disabilities, but
rather the need for a location to stop a vehicle which carries a person or
persons with disabilities only long enough to drop off or pick up such person
or persons from a designated place. The regular use of special motor vehicles
or buses for the transport of persons with disabilities to and from a
designated place shall be considered as evidence indicating the need for a drop
off zone for persons with disabilities, rather than the need for parking for
persons with disabilities. (Ord. 2006-0-20, 4-3-06)
   C.   Disabled Permit Parking Established: There is hereby created permit
parking for the disabled on public streets within the Village, subject to the
following restriction, requirements and minimal fees.
      1.   Application For Permit Parking: A disabled person shall be issued a
disabled parking permit for parking on the public way within the Village if
such person satisfies the following requirements:
         a.   The applicant for disabled permit parking is a resident of the
Village of Oak Park.
         b.   The applicant or member of the applicant's household who
transports the applicant in the applicant's vehicle possesses a valid, current
driver's license within the state.
         c.   The vehicle to be parked in the disabled permit parking space is
owned by such applicant and possesses current, valid state registration and
Village vehicle license.
         d.   The applicant has no current outstanding parking citations with
the Village of Oak Park.
         e.   The applicant either possesses disabled State registration plates
or a current State disabled certificate issued to the applicant.
         f.   The applicant is able to establish that the issuance of a
disabled parking permit to the applicant will alleviate some demonstrable
hardship presently borne by the applicant.
      2.   Proof Of Hardship: The applicant for the disabled parking permit
must establish to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Works or the
Director's designee that the issuance of the disabled parking permit will
alleviate some demonstrable hardship presently borne by the applicant.
Applicants who possess off street parking which is easily accessible from the
applicant's dwelling will be presumed not to have a hardship which will be
relieved by the issuance of a disabled parking permit. There shall also be a
presumption that applicants who reside in single- family dwellings with side
drives which are accessible from the street are not subject to a hardship which
will be relieved by the issuance of a disabled parking permit.
      3.   Permits Approved By The Director Of Public Works And Issued By The
Parking Permit Office: The Director of Public Works or the Director's designee
shall be responsible for approving all applications for disabled parking
permits applied for hereunder. The Parking Director shall be responsible for
accepting, processing and issuing disabled parking permits and verifying the
applicant's compliance with licensing, certification and registration
requirements and the fact that the applicant has no outstanding Village parking
citations attributable to the applicant or applicant's vehicle prior to
issuance.
      4.   Disabled Parking Permits; Parking Regulations; Overnight Parking
Ban: The disabled parking permit shall be affixed to the lower right hand
corner of the rear windshield of the applicant's vehicle. The appropriately
affixed disabled parking permit will entitle the applicant, when driving such
vehicle, to the exclusive use of the permit parking space to which that permit
is allocated. Such vehicle, while parked in the designated permit parking
space, will not be subject to parking regulations related to time, such as No
Parking 8–10 A.M. or 2 Hour Parking.
The disabled parking permit shall not, however, override the overnight parking
ban in effect throughout the Village. (Ord. 1995-0-37, 6-5-1995)
      5.   Permit Fees:
         a.   There shall be a onetime charge of twenty dollars ($20.00) for
the installation of disabled permit parking signage and an annual disabled
parking permit fee of ten dollars ($10.00).
         b.   The renewal of the disabled parking permit shall be due on July 1
of each year.
         c.   The disabled parking permit fee for the first year will be
reduced to five dollars ($5.00) if the time period between the issuance of the
initial permit and the following July 1 is less than six (6) months. (Ord.
1996-0-12, 2-20-1996)
15-1-25: AUTHORIZED TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNALS AND PARKING REGULATIONS:
Each traffic control signal, stop sign, parking regulation sign, parking meter
or other traffic control device erected by the Village or the State and
existing on the effective date of this Code is designated, authorized, approved
and adopted for the purpose of regulating parking and traffic, pursuant to the
provisions of this Code. (1981 Code)
15-1-26: PARKING OFFENSES RELATED TO TIME RESTRICTIONS, TIME LIMITS AND
PROHIBITED PARKING FOR DESIGNATED AREAS:
It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle in violation of the time restrictions
(e.g., no parking 8:00 to 10:00 A.M.), time limits (e.g., 2 hours maximum
parking) and prohibited parking areas designated on the map attached as exhibit
A to the ordinance codified herein provided such areas are properly posted with
signage that clearly sets forth such parking time restrictions, time
limitations or prohibitions.
The map attached as exhibit A to the ordinance codified herein shall be updated
by ordinance amendment on a semiannual basis. (Ord. 2011-0-22, 5-16-2011)
15-1-27: PARKING IN A TOW:
   A.   At the times herein specified and as designated by authorized signage,
no person shall directly or indirectly park or permit a vehicle owned or
controlled by said person to be parked at the locations on the streets set
forth below which are designated as tow zones Monday through Sunday from ten
o’clock (10:00) P.M. to two-thirty o’clock (2:30) A.M.:
      1.   The 1150 to 1200 block of South Cuyler Avenue;
      2.   The 1150 to 1200 block of South Harvey Avenue;
      3.   The 1150 to 1200 block of South Highland Avenue; and
      4.   The 1150 to 1200 block of South Ridgeland Avenue.
   B.   The specifically prohibited tow zone areas from which vehicles may be
towed shall be posted by the Village with a notice at or near the sign
identifying the prohibited parking which provides "TOW ZONE" or with a
reasonable notice which conveys substantially similar information. No person
shall directly or indirectly or permit a vehicle owned or controlled by that
person to be parked in the Village in violation of any such prohibited parking.
All Village police officers shall have the authority to authorize the towing,
removal and storage of such a vehicle.
   C.   Residents of the blocks set forth in subsection A above who have
current Village vehicle licenses may park their vehicles during the designated
tow zone dates and times and shall not be considered unlawfully parked when a
resident parks their vehicle on a block on which they reside. Guests of such
residents shall be eligible to obtain Village guest passes to park within a tow
zone and shall not be considered unlawfully parked during the applicable period
of time for which a guest pass has been issued by the Village. Passes shall be
obtained in a form designated by the Village. (Ord. 23-38, 5-15-2023)
ARTICLE 2
BICYCLES
SECTION:
15-2-1: Definitions
15-2-2: Effect Of Bicycle Regulations
15-2-3: Traffic Laws To Apply To Persons Riding Bicycles
15-2-4: Speed Of Bicycles
15-2-5: Emerging From Alley, Driveway Or Building
15-2-6: Riding Bicycles On Sidewalks
15-2-7: Riding Bicycles On Street And Bicycle Paths
15-2-8: Clinging To Moving Vehicle
15-2-9: Carrying Articles On Bicycles
15-2-10: Parking
15-2-11: Lighted Lamps And Audible Signaling Devices On Bicycles
15-2-12: Riding On Bicycles
15-2-13: Obedience To Traffic Control Devices
15-2-14: License Required
15-2-15: License Application; Fee
15-2-16: License Issuance
15-2-17: Attachment Of License Decal
15-2-18: Inspection
15-2-19: Transfer Of Ownership
15-2-20: Serial Number
15-2-21: Buying Or Selling Bicycles
15-2-22: Rental Agencies
15-2-23: Bicycle Helmets Required
15-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section as follows:
BICYCLE: Any device propelled by human power upon which any person or persons
may ride, having two (2) or more wheels, any of which is more than sixteen
inches (16") in diameter.
MINOR: Any person who has not attained the age of seventeen (17) years.
PARENT OR GUARDIAN: Any person having legal custody of a minor who is: a) a
natural or adoptive parent; b) a legal guardian; c) a person who stands in loco
parentis; or d) a person to whom legal custody has been given by court order.
(Ord. 2013-0-68, 12-2-2013)
15-2-2: EFFECT OF BICYCLE REGULATIONS:
   A.   The regulations in this chapter applicable to bicycles shall apply
whenever a bicycle is operated upon any street or public sidewalk or upon any
public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those
exceptions stated herein.
   B.   The parent or guardian of any minor shall not authorize or knowingly
permit any such minor to violate any of the provisions of this chapter
applicable to bicycles. (Ord. 2013-0-68, 12-2-2013)
15-2-3: TRAFFIC LAWS TO APPLY TO PERSONS RIDING BICYCLES:
Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be subject to all of the
duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of this state
declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles, or by the traffic
ordinances of this Village applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to
those provisions of laws and ordinances which by their nature can have no
application. (1981 Code)
15-2-4: SPEED OF BICYCLES:
No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and
prudent under the conditions then existing and, in any case, not beyond the
posted speed limit. (1981 Code)
15-2-5: EMERGING FROM ALLEY, DRIVEWAY OR BUILDING:
The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall,
upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway,
yield the right of way to all pedestrians approaching on said sidewalk or
sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right of way to
vehicles approaching on said roadway. (1981 Code)
15-2-6: RIDING BICYCLES ON SIDEWALKS:
   A.   No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business
district.
   B.   No person fifteen (15) or more years of age shall ride a bicycle upon
any sidewalk in any zoning district.
   C.   Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk such person
shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signal
before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. (1981 Code)
15-2-7: RIDING BICYCLES ON STREET AND BICYCLE PATHS:
   A.   Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to
the right hand side of the roadway as practicable exercising due care when
passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction.
   B.   Bicycles shall not be operated upon any street where the operation of
bicycles has been prohibited, and signs have been erected indicating such
prohibition.
   C.   Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride other than single
file except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of
bicycles.
   D.   Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a
roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and not use the roadway. (Ord.
2013-0-16, 2-19-2013)
15-2-8: CLINGING TO MOVING VEHICLE:
Any person riding upon any bicycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy
vehicle shall not attach the same or himself to any moving vehicle upon any
roadway. (1981 Code)
15-2-9: CARRYING ARTICLES ON BICYCLES:
No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article which
prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon the handlebars. (1981
Code)
15-2-10: PARKING:
No person shall park a bicycle upon a street. Bicycles may be parked upon the
sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or at the curb in such a manner as to
afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic or against a building. (1981
Code)
15-2-11: LIGHTED LAMPS AND AUDIBLE SIGNALING DEVICES ON BICYCLES:
   A.   Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a
headlamp which shall emit a white light visible from a minimum distance of five
hundred feet (500') from the front, and with a red reflector on the rear of a
type approved by the Secretary of State or with a rear lamp emitting a red
light visible from a minimum distance of at least five hundred feet (500') from
the rear.
   B.   No person shall operate a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or
other device capable of giving a signal audible for at least one hundred feet
(100'), except that a bicycle shall not be equipped with, nor shall any person
use upon a bicycle, any siren or whistle. (1981 Code)
   C.   Every bicycle shall be equipped with side reflectors attached to the
wheels which are visible from a distance of five hundred feet (500'). The
required colors shall be red in the rear half of the bike and amber in the
front.
   D.   Every bicycle shall be equipped with an effective brake. (Ord. 1983-0-
12, 3-21-1983)
15-2-12: RIDING ON BICYCLES:
   A.   A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride a
permanent and regular seat attached thereto.
   B.   No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the
number for which it is designed and equipped. (1981 Code)
15-2-13: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
   A.   Any person operating a bicycle shall comply with official traffic
control signals, signs and other control devices applicable to vehicles, unless
otherwise directed by a police officer.
   B.   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left
turn or a turn in the opposite direction is permitted, no person operating a
bicycle shall disobey the direction of any such sign, except where such person
dismounts from the bicycle to make any such turn, in which event such person
shall then obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians. (1981 Code)
15-2-14: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person who resides in the Village shall ride or propel a bicycle on any
street or upon any public way within the Village unless such bicycle has been
licensed and the license decal is attached thereto as prescribed herein. (1981
Code; amd. Ord. 1983-0-12, 3-21-1983)
15-2-15: LICENSE APPLICATION; FEE:
Application for a bicycle license shall be made upon a form provided by the
Village and shall be made to the Village Clerk. A license fee of one dollar
($1.00) shall be paid to the Village before a license is granted. This license
shall be valid until such time as the ownership of the bicycle is transferred.
(1981 Code)
15-2-16: LICENSE ISSUANCE:
The Village Clerk, upon receiving the proper application and fee, upon approval
by the Chief of Police as authorized in section
15-2-18 of this article, is authorized to issue a license decal, which shall be
attached to the bicycle and an identification card as prescribed by the Police
Department, containing the name and address of the owner along with a complete
description of the bicycle which may be carried by the owner and displayed when
requested by a police officer to verify ownership of the bicycle. (1981 Code;
amd. Ord. 1983-0-12, 3-21-1983)
The Chief of Police may not approve the issuance of a license for any bicycle
when he knows or has reasonable grounds to believe the applicant is not the
owner of, or entitled to the possession of, such bicycle.
The Village Clerk shall keep a record of the number of each bicycle registered,
the name and address of the person to whom the license was issued, and the
color and serial number of the bicycle for which the license was issued. (1981
Code)
15-2-17: ATTACHMENT OF LICENSE DECAL:
Upon issuance of a bicycle license decal, which shall contain the name OAK
PARK, ILLINOIS, and a number, the licensee shall cause the same to be affixed
firmly on the front of the vertical frame between the seat and the pedal
mechanism of the bicycle for which the license is issued. (Ord. 1983-0-12, 3-
21-1983)
This license shall be permanently assigned to this bicycle and no person shall
remove this license from the bicycle, except upon transfer of ownership or in
the event the bicycle is wrecked, junked or dismantled and is no longer used
upon the streets of the Village. (1981 Code)
15-2-18: INSPECTION:
The Chief of Police may cause the inspection of any bicycle and shall refuse to
approve a license for any bicycle in an unsafe mechanical condition. (1981
Code)
15-2-19: TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP:
Upon the sale of the bicycle, the license shall be removed and the Village
Clerk notified that the bicycle is no longer in the possession of the former
owner. If the new owner resides in the Village, the bicycle shall be registered
by him and a new license obtained. (1981 Code)
15-2-20: SERIAL NUMBER:
It shall be unlawful to destroy, remove, alter, cover or deface the
manufacturer's serial number on any bicycle. It shall be unlawful for any
person to own or have custody of a bicycle on which the original serial number
has been destroyed, altered, removed, covered or defaced. In the event a
bicycle has been purchased, which does not contain a manufacturer's serial
number, the Police Department shall stamp an original serial number on the
frame of the bicycle and this number shall be considered the original number.
(1981 Code)
15-2-21: BUYING OR SELLING BICYCLES:
Every person engaged in the business of buying, selling or exchanging bicycles
in the Village shall maintain for five (5) years a record containing the name,
color, type and serial number of each bicycle bought, sold or exchanged. Said
record shall further contain the name and address of each person buying,
selling or exchanging a bicycle, which record shall be open to inspection by a
representative of the Police Department during reasonable business hours. (1981
Code)
15-2-22: RENTAL AGENCIES:
A rental agency shall not rent or offer to rent any bicycle unless the bicycle
is licensed and the license decal is firmly attached as provided herein and
such bicycle is equipped with lamps and other equipment as required in this
article. (1981 Code; amd. Ord. 1983-0-12, 3-21-1983)
15-2-23: BICYCLE HELMETS REQUIRED:
   A.   Helmet Required: Every person under the age of seventeen (17) years
shall wear a protective helmet meeting nationally recognized safety
requirements whenever that person is upon a public highway, sidewalk, bicycle
path or other public right of way within the corporate limits of the Village
and is riding or being carried on any bicycle or any carrier attached to or
pulled by a bicycle.
   B.   Compliance: Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary,
compliance with this section may be demonstrated by proof of possession of a
helmet that meets nationally recognized safety requirements, and solely with
respect to the first such violation, there shall be no penalty if such
compliance is so demonstrated.
   C.   Admissibility In A Civil Action: A violation of this section shall not
constitute negligence, contributory negligence, assumption of risk, be
considered in mitigation of damages of whatever nature, be admissible in
evidence, or be the subject of comment by counsel in any action for the
recovery of damages arising out of the operation of any bicycle, nor shall
anything in this section change any existing law, rule, or procedure pertaining
to any civil action.
   D.   Parental Responsibility: It shall be unlawful for a parent or guardian
to knowingly or negligently permit or cause a minor under the age of seventeen
(17) years to be upon a public highway, sidewalk, bicycle path or other public
right of way within the corporate limits of the Village while riding or being
carried on any bicycle or any carrier attached to or pulled by a bicycle
without wearing a protective helmet meeting nationally recognized safety
requirements pursuant to this section.
   E.   Penalty: A violation of this section shall be punishable by a maximum
term of four (4) hours of community service or a fine not to exceed twenty five
dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 2013-0-68, 12-2-2013)
ARTICLE 3
PARKING METERS, PARKING PERMITS AND MUNICIPAL ATTENDANT PARKING LOTS
SECTION:
15-3-1: Definitions
15-3-2: Construction Of Article
15-3-3: Duty Of Director Of Public Works To Install Parking Meters And Mark Off
Parking Meter Spaces
15-3-4: Board Of Trustees To Fix Time Limitations On Parking; How Time
Limitations Indicated
15-3-5: Payment For Parking Meters And Installment Thereof
15-3-6: Where Parking Meters To Be Placed; Signal; Legend
15-3-7: Designation And Use Of Parking Meter Spaces
15-3-8: Duty Of Operator When Parking Vehicle
15-3-9: Occupation Of Parking On Or Off Street Meter Spaces Upon Deposit Of
Coins; Pay By Space; Overtime Parking
15-3-10: Defacing, Injuring, Etc., Parking Meters
15-3-11: Defrauding Parking Meters Or Coin Operated Gates
15-3-12: Duty Of Police Officers With Reference To Violations; Payment Of Fines
15-3-13: Collection And Disposition Of Parking Meter Money And Fines
15-3-14: Municipal Parking Lots And Parking Enclaves; Overtime Parking
15-3-15: Parking Enclaves
15-3-16: Overnight Parking Permits
15-3-17: Enclave Parking Reports
15-3-18: Parking Rates; Parking Meters, Pay By Space Machines, Village Operated
Parking Structures, Permit, Extended Pass, Valet And Daytime On Street Permit
Parking
15-3-19: On Street Overnight Parking Passes
15-3-20: Valet Public Parking Fees
15-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases shall have the meanings, and are hereby
defined, as follows:
ATTENDANT PARKING: The parking of a vehicle in a Village attendant parking lot
during those times when a Village parking lot attendant is present.
METERED PARKING: The parking of a vehicle in a parking meter zone during the
time designated on the parking meter regulating said zone.
PARKING METER: A mechanical device located in any public parking lot or upon a
public street or sidewalk in a place regularly designated as a "parking meter
zone" as defined in this section, which device shall record a certain number of
minutes by the use of a clock mechanism determining the period of time for
which parking privileges may be extended to the person so depositing a coin.
PARKING METER ZONE: A certain designated and marked off section of the public
street within the marked boundaries of which a vehicle may be temporarily
parked and allowed to remain for such period of time as the parking meter
attached thereto may indicate.
ROADWAY: That portion of a street between the regularly established curb lines.
SIDEWALK: That portion of a street between the curb lines and the adjacent
property lines.
STREET: Every way set apart for public travel, except alleys.
VEHICLE: Any device by which any person or property may be transported upon a
public highway.
VEHICLE ATTENDANT PARKING LOTS: A parking lot operated by the Village for the
parking of vehicles by the general public, the use of which shall require
payment of a fee in accordance with an approved and posted fee schedule to a
Village parking lot attendant upon exiting the parking lot in a vehicle at all
times when a Village parking lot attendant is present. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-
2010)
15-3-2: CONSTRUCTION OF ARTICLE:
This article shall be deemed to be in addition and supplementary to and not in
conflict with nor a repeal of prior or existing ordinances of the Village, but
shall be an additional provision for the regulation of traffic and parking in
the parking meter zones created and provided for by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-3: DUTY OF DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS TO INSTALL PARKING METERS AND MARK OFF
PARKING METER SPACES:
In parking meter zones the Director of Public Works shall cause parking meters
to be installed in such numbers and at such places as in his judgment may be
necessary for the regulation, control and inspection of the parking vehicles
therein, including the reservation of loading zones for commercial vehicles,
and shall cause parking meter spaces to be designated as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-4: BOARD OF TRUSTEES TO FIX TIME LIMITATIONS ON PARKING; HOW TIME
LIMITATIONS INDICATED:
The Board of Trustees shall fix the time limitations for legal parking in
parking meter zones and the hours during the day when the parking meters must
be used and when the time limitations shall be effective, in compliance with
the provisions of this article, and shall indicate the time limitations by
designating the same on the parking meters or by appropriate signs posted in
proximity to the meters in parking meter zones. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-5: PAYMENT FOR PARKING METERS AND INSTALLMENT THEREOF:
The payment for parking meters and installation thereof shall be provided for
solely from the receipts, funds and revenues obtained from the operation of
such parking meters without in any manner obligating the Village to pay for the
same from any other source. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-6: WHERE PARKING METERS TO BE PLACED; SIGNAL; LEGEND:
The parking meters installed in the parking meter zones as established by the
Board of Trustees shall be placed upon the curb immediately adjacent to the
individual parking places hereinafter described. Each parking meter shall be
placed or set in such a manner as to show or display by a signal that the
parking space adjacent to such meter is or is not legally in use. Each parking
meter installed shall indicate by a proper legend the legal parking time
established by the Village. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-7: DESIGNATION AND USE OF PARKING METER SPACES:
The Director of Public Works shall have markings painted or placed upon the
curb and the street, either or both, adjacent to each parking meter for the
purpose of designating the parking space for which such meter is to be used.
Each vehicle parking adjacent or next to any parking meter shall park within
the lines or markings so established. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle
across any such line or marking or to park such vehicle in such position that
the same shall not entirely fit within the area so designated by such lines or
markings. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-8: DUTY OF OPERATOR WHEN PARKING VEHICLE:
When any vehicle shall be parked in any space adjacent to which a parking meter
is located, in accordance with the provisions of this article, the operator of
such vehicle shall, upon entering such parking space, immediately deposit or
cause to be deposited a coin of the United States, in such parking meter, and
put such meter in operation; failure to deposit such coin and put the meter in
operation shall be unlawful. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-9: OCCUPATION OF PARKING ON OR OFF STREET METER SPACES UPON DEPOSIT OF
COINS; PAY BY SPACE; OVERTIME PARKING:
   A.   Upon placing a meter in operation as provided in this article or paying
by space, the parking space may be lawfully occupied by such vehicle for a
period indicated thereon for the coin or coins specified.
   B.   If any such vehicle shall remain parked in such parking space beyond
the parking time limit as fixed by the payment for such meter or payment by
space for such parking space, the parking meter or pay by space machine shall,
by its dial and pointer or other applicable time measurement, indicate such
illegal parking; in that event such vehicle shall be considered parked overtime
and beyond the period of legal parking time and shall be unlawful. (Ord. 15-
197, 12-7-2015, eff. 7-1-2016)
15-3-10: DEFACING, INJURING, ETC., PARKING METERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, injure, tamper with, open or
wilfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed
under the provisions of this article. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-11: DEFRAUDING PARKING METERS OR COIN OPERATED GATES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited in any
parking meter or coin operated gate, any slug, device or metallic substitute,
or any other substitute for any coin of the United States. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-
15-2010)
15-3-12: DUTY OF POLICE OFFICERS WITH REFERENCE TO VIOLATIONS; PAYMENT OF
FINES:
It shall be the duty of the police officers or parking meter patrol persons of
the Village to report:
   A.   The number of each parking meter which indicated that the vehicle
occupying the parking space adjacent to such parking meter is or has been
parking in violation of any of the provisions of this article.
   B.   The state license number of such vehicle.
   C.   The time such vehicle is parking in violation of any of the provisions
of this article.
   D.   Any other facts or knowledge of which is necessary to a thorough
understanding of the circumstances attending such violation.
Each such police officer or parking patrol person shall attach to such vehicle
a notice to the owner or operator thereof that such vehicle has been parked in
violation of a provision of this article. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-13: COLLECTION AND DISPOSITION OF PARKING METER MONEY AND FINES:
All money from parking meters and fines collected shall be deposited with the
Director of Finance; provided, however, that a separate fund to be known as the
parking meter fund shall be maintained at all times for the accurate recording
of such money and fines so deposited. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-14: MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS AND PARKING ENCLAVES; OVERTIME PARKING:
No person shall park in any parking space in any municipally owned garage,
parking lot or parking enclave beyond parking limits established by the Board
of Trustees, or if equipped with meters, beyond the parking time limits fixed
by the coins deposited in the meter for the parking space. The provisions of
sections
15-3-8 through
15-3-11 of this article relating to parking meters shall apply to this section.
(Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-15: PARKING ENCLAVES:
The Board of Trustees may establish all night permit parking enclaves within
the dedicated right of way of public streets, provided said enclaves meet the
following criteria:
   A.   Curb cut and cul-de-sac parking enclaves must be separate from the
physical flow of normal street traffic. Enclaves will also be permitted where
adjacent to the Chicago and Northwestern or Eisenhower Expressway embankments,
as parking in these unique areas does not affect street cleaning or leaf and
snow removal to as great an extent as normally traveled street areas.
   B.   The proposed parking enclave will not have a substantial negative
impact on police protection.
   C.   The area must be in or adjacent to areas having the severest parking
space shortages in the Village.
   D.   Curb cut parking enclaves shall not be permitted if there is a
substantially negative effect on grassed parkways.
All night parking shall be permitted in parking enclaves only on monthly permit
basis. Each vehicle shall be identified with a parking sticker to facilitate
police identification and protection. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-16: OVERNIGHT PARKING PERMITS:
All night permit parking from six o'clock (6:00) P.M. to eight o'clock (8:00)
A.M. shall be permitted in parking enclaves, except that the permit parking
hours at a given enclave location may be varied by resolution of the President
and Board of Trustees, based upon the unique parking needs of the area. Permits
shall be issued only to persons residing within four (4) blocks of the parking
area designated, with a priority to those residing closest to the parking
spaces. A permit sticker shall be issued by the Village to be affixed to the
rear window of the vehicle. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-17: ENCLAVE PARKING REPORTS:
The Chief of Police and the Director of Public Works shall report annually to
the Board of Trustees on or about July 1 regarding the effect of the
establishment of parking enclaves on police protection, street cleaning, and
leaf and snow removal. The continuation or addition of parking enclaves shall
be reviewed by the Board of Trustees after the receipt of the annual report.
(Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010)
15-3-18: PARKING RATES; PARKING METERS, PAY BY SPACE MACHINES, VILLAGE OPERATED
PARKING STRUCTURES, PERMIT, EXTENDED PASS, VALET AND DAYTIME ON STREET PERMIT
PARKING:
Persons parking vehicles in Village owned and/or operated parking spaces
designated by the Village for use by the general public as metered pay by
plate, Village operated parking structures, permit parking, overnight pass
parking shall pay a fee to the Village in accordance with the following rate
schedule:
   A.   High Parking Demand Area: Pay by plate machine and parking meter rates
for all persons in the high parking demand area from and including Harlem on
the west to and including Euclid on the east and from and including Ontario
(from Harlem to Kenilworth) and Lake Street (from Kenilworth to Euclid) on the
north to and including the north side of North Boulevard on the south and
excluding from the high parking demand area all commuter areas set forth in
subsection
15-3-18C of this section and depicted on the map hereinafter set forth as map
exhibit 1 on file with the Village except the following locations:
      Marion Street south of South Boulevard
      Pleasant Street, between south Marion Street and the north-south alley
east of Marion Street
      Pleasant Street, between south Marion Street and the north-south alley
west of Marion Street
   All pay by plate machines: The fee shall be fifty cents ($0.50) for each
fifteen (15) minutes of parking for the first three (3) hours after which the
fee shall be one dollar and fifty cents for each fifteen (15) minutes of
parking.
      2.   All pay by plate and metered parking shall be free of charge for up
to two (2) hours at pay by plate and metered parking spaces from Ontario Street
on the north to Pleasant Street on the south, including south Marion Street, to
Harlem Avenue on the west to Euclid Avenue on the east, on the following dates:
      July 4
      The day after Thanksgiving Day
      Every Saturday that falls after Thanksgiving Day and prior to December 25
   Unless otherwise set forth in this section, the rate for each pay by plate
machine and parking meter shall be the rate set forth on the face of the
machine and/or meter as previously approved by the Village Board.
   B.   Medium Parking Demand Areas: Pay by plate machine and parking meter
rates in the medium parking demand areas as depicted on the map hereinafter set
forth as map exhibit 1, on file with the Village, and described as follows:
   Area 1: Harlem on the west to and including Euclid on the east and from

of Lake (from Kenilworth to Euclid) on the south.
   Area 2: Harlem on the west to and including East on the east and from South

   Area 5: Grove on the west to and including Wesley on the east, and from Van

   Area 6: Highland on the west to and including Lombard on the east and from
Van Buren on the north to and including Flournoy on the south.
   Area 7:
   Area 8:

   E.   Oak Park Business Employee Discount Parking At Village Designated
Public Parking Locations:
      1.   Employers of full and part time employees who work within Oak Park
may purchase from the Village a discount parking reduced fee card in designated
public parking locations for their employees.
      2.   Employers may purchase a reduced fee card for each of their
employees by providing the full name, work status (full or part time), hourly
rate of pay and vehicle identification, registration, make and model
information to the Village.
      3.   Each quarterly reduced fee card shall cost three dollars ($3.00).
      4.   Reduced fee cards shall be sold to Oak Park employers for the
benefit of their employees who work in Oak Park and earn an hourly wage of
twenty dollars ($20.00) per hour or less on a first come, first served basis.
Reduced fee cards shall be sold on a quarterly basis and may be purchased by
employers between the fifteenth day of the month preceding the start of the
quarter and the fifth day of the first month of said quarter and the fifth of
the following month on a first come, first serve basis. Once purchased reduced
fee cards are nonrefundable.
      5.   If it is determined that either an employer or their employee has
used a reduced fee card in a manner inconsistent with this section, the
employer shall be prohibited from purchasing employee discount parking.
      6.   Employee parking shall be available in the following lots:
         a.   Two hundred (200) spaces at the Holley Court Garage at 1125
Ontario, roof level only.
         b.   One hundred and fifty (150) spaces at the Avenue Garage at 720
North Boulevard, roof level only.
      7.   The Development Customer Services Director shall establish the
actual number of reduced fee cards that may be sold per quarter based upon
utilization.

   G.   Oak Park River Forest High School Parking Structure: The fee for
parking in Village operated multilevel parking structures known as the Oak Park
River Forest High School shall be fifty cents ($0.50) per hour during times
designated as public parking. The hourly parking fee shall be eliminated during
times that the parking structure is reserved for Friday evening football
parking established by special use permit. Public parking in the Oak Park River
Forest High School shall be free during farmers' market Saturdays.
   H.   High Volume Business Parking Validation Program:
      1.   High Volume Business Parking Validation Program; Authorized For
Holley Court Multilevel Parking Structure:
         a.   Businesses patronized by customers on a high volume, short
duration daily basis, shall be eligible for participation in the Village
Parking Validation Program.
         b.   Businesses which are patronized by more than four thousand
(4,000) customers per week for an average of at least one and one-half (11/2)
hours per visit shall be eligible for participation in the Village's High
Volume Business Parking Validation Program ("program").
         c.   Participation in the program shall provide the participating
business with the ability to offer its customers up to one hour of free parking
in the Holley Court multilevel parking structure in addition to the one free
hour of parking already provided by the Village to all members of the public
who park in the structure.
         d.   The participating business shall acquire at its own cost the
specific ticket validation machine authorized by the Village as compatible with
Village equipment and update and/or replace same as required by Village.
            (1)   The machine shall be encoded by the Village with a code which
will identify the participating business on each parking ticket validated by
the machine; and
            (2)   The machine shall be programmed by the Village to provide
each validated ticket with one hour of free parking in addition to the first
hour of free parking provided by the Village to all members of the public who
park in the structure.
               (A)   The Village shall charge the participating business a fee
of fifty cents ($0.50) per one hour of free parking authorized by each
validated parking ticket.
               (B)   The validation machine shall be maintained on the premises
of the participating business and shall be used by the business to validate the
parking tickets provided by the Holley Court parking structure system to the
business' customers.
               (C)   At the time a business enters the program, the Village
shall estimate the number of customer parking tickets in the Holley Court
multilevel parking structure which shall be validated by that business each
month and shall multiply that number by fifty cents ($0.50) and shall bill that
total amount to the business fifteen (15) days prior to the first of each month
for which ticket validation is provided for the first six (6) months the
business is in the program.
               (D)   The participating business shall provide the Village with
full payment of the monthly bill within fifteen (15) days of receipt of same.
               (E)   At the end of the first six (6) months of each business'
participation in the Validation Program and each six (6) months thereafter, the
Village shall determine the actual average number of business customers
participating in the Validation Program and shall multiply that number by fifty
cents ($0.50) and shall bill the business on a monthly basis at the newly
established rate for the subsequent six (6) month period.
               (F)   The participating business shall provide ticket validation
to its customers only.
               (G)   The participating business shall cooperate fully with the
Village in providing the Village with access to the validation machine and
customer attendance records as the Village deems necessary for the Village to
effectively administer the program.
               (H)   The Village shall provide the participating business upon
request with the calculation upon which the new billing is based and copies of
the record information upon which such calculation is based.
               (I)   In the event that a participating business violates the
terms and conditions of the Validation Program, the Village reserves the right
to suspend or terminate the business' participation in the program upon giving
the business at least ten (10) days' prior written notice of said violation(s)
and an opportunity to respond to or correct same before suspending or
terminating same.
   I.   Village Operated Surface Parking Lot, Parking Garage And Public Way
Parking Enclave Permit Parking Rates:
      1.   Village Operated Surface Parking Lots: Parking in Village operated
surface parking lots shall only be permitted in pay by plate parking spaces,
metered parking spaces, by permit, in designated parking spaces. Such lots may
operate exclusively as pay by plate or metered parking lots or exclusively as
permit parking only lots or may operate with a combination of pay by plate,
metered, and permit parking spaces.
   No overnight parking shall be permitted in Village operated surface parking
lots without a Village issued overnight parking permit.
      2.   Village Operated Parking Garage Monthly Permit Parking Rates:
Parking permits allowing for twenty four (24) hour parking in the Holley Court
and Avenue multilevel parking structures shall be sold for one hundred fifty-
seven dollars ($157.00) per vehicle, per month.
      3.   Village Operated Multilevel Parking Structure, Parking Lot And
Enclave Public Way Parking Quarterly Permit Parking Rates: Parking permits
allowing for twenty four (24) hour, daytime and overnight parking in Village-
operated multilevel parking structures, permit lots, and public way permit
parking enclaves shall be sold at the following rates:
         a.   High Demand Area Permit Parking Lots And Public Way Enclaves: In
Village-operated permit parking lots, and public way permit parking enclaves
located within the high parking demand area as designated in subsection 15-3-
18A of this section, rates shall be as follows:

fifty seven dollars ($257.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (B)   Daytime permit parking only: Two hundred twenty seven
dollars ($227.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (C)   Overnight permit parking only: One hundred seventy seven
dollars ($177.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
            (2)   Nonresident Rates:
               (A)   Twenty four (24) hour a day permit parking: Three hundred
thirty two dollars ($332.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (B)   Daytime permit parking only: Two hundred eighty two
dollars ($282.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (C)   Overnight permit parking only: One hundred ninety seven
dollars ($197.00) per vehicle, per quarter.

licensed business located in the Village of Oak Park which has made application
to the Village and been designated as a corporate account for the purposes of
quarterly parking permits and purchases a minimum of five (5) quarterly
permits, per quarter.

fifty seven dollars ($257.00) per vehicle, per quarter.

dollars ($227.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (C)   Overnight permit parking only: One hundred seventy seven
dollars ($177.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
         b.   High Demand Area Multilevel Parking Structures: In Village-
operated multilevel parking structures located within the high parking demand
area as designated in subsection
15-3-18A of this section, rates shall be as follows:

ninety-two dollars ($292.00) per vehicle, per quarter.

($262.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (C)   Overnight permit parking only: Two hundred and twelve
dollars ($212.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
         c.   Permit Parking Lots And Public Way Enclaves Outside High Demand
Areas: In all Village-operated permit lots, and public way permit parking

         d.   Multilevel Parking Structures Outside High Demand Area: In all
Village-operated multilevel parking structures located outside the high demand
parking area set forth in subsection 15-3-18A of this section, the rates shall
be as follows:
            (1)   Resident Rates:
               (A)   Twenty four (24) hour a day permit parking: Two hundred
thirty two dollars ($232.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (B)   Daytime permit parking only: One hundred ninety seven
dollars ($197.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (C)   Overnight permit parking only: One hundred sixty two
dollars ($162.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
            (2)   Nonresident Rates:
               (A)   Twenty four (24) hour a day permit parking: Two hundred
ninety two dollars ($292.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (B)   Daytime permit parking only: Two hundred forty seven
dollars ($247.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (C)   Overnight permit parking only: Two hundred two dollars
($202.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
            (3)   Corporate Rates: Corporate rates shall only apply to a
licensed business located in the Village of Oak Park which has made application
to the Village and been designated as a corporate account for the purposes of
quarterly parking permits and purchases a minimum of five (5) quarterly
permits, per quarter.
               (A)   Twenty four (24) hour a day permit parking: Two hundred
thirty two dollars ($232.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (B)   Daytime permit parking only: One hundred ninety seven
dollars ($197.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (C)   Overnight permit parking only: One hundred sixty two
dollars ($162.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
         e.   Commuter Areas: Commuter lot permit fees for commuter permit
parking in areas defined in subsection
15-3-18C of this section.
            (1)   Resident Rates:
               (A)   Twenty four (24) hour a day permit parking: Two hundred
twenty seven dollars ($227.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (B)   Daytime permit parking only: Two hundred seventeen dollars
($217.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (C)   Overnight permit parking only: One hundred fifty two
dollars ($152.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
            (2)   Nonresident Rates:
               (A)   Twenty four (24) hour a day permit parking: Two hundred
eighty seven dollars ($287.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (B)   Daytime permit parking only: Two hundred seventy two
dollars ($272.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (C)   Overnight permit parking only: One hundred ninety two
dollars ($192.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
            (3)   Corporate Rates: Corporate rates shall only apply to a
licensed business located in the Village of Oak Park which has made application
to the Village and been designated as a corporate account for the purposes of
quarterly parking permits and purchases a minimum of five (5) quarterly
permits, per quarter.
               (A)   Twenty four (24) hour a day permit parking: Two hundred
twenty seven dollars ($227.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (B)   Daytime permit parking only: Two hundred seventeen dollars
($217.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
               (C)   Overnight permit parking only: One hundred fifty two
dollars ($152.00) per vehicle, per quarter.
   J.   Daytime On Street Permit Parking Fee: Permit fees for all daytime on-
street parking permits, other than parking permits for the disabled, issued for
all daytime on-street permit parking areas authorized by ordinance of the
President of the Board of Trustees shall be as follows:
   Handicapped permits: Ten dollars ($10.00) per year.
   Resident permits: Seventy four dollars ($74.00) per year.
   Guest day passes; books of twenty (20): Five dollars ($5.00) per book.
   Business Residential Parking Permit Program: Any business that provides
services to residences in the Village shall be eligible for an annual business
daytime on-street permit at a rate of one hundred twenty four dollars ($124.00)
per year for a business licensed by the Village and at a rate of one hundred
fifty five dollars ($155.00) for a business not licensed by the Village that
may be used for up to five (5) vehicles, which includes business vehicles or
private vehicles used by employees of the business. Said permit shall override
all of the Village’s street time limit restrictions except prohibited parking
hours of seven o’clock (7:00) A.M. to nine o’clock (9:00) A.M. or four o’clock
(4:00) P.M. to six o’clock (6:00) P.M., but shall not override any Village
street cleaning restrictions, any Village safety-related restrictions, such as
“no parking anytime” or parking within a prohibited area because of a fire
hydrant, or the Village’s overnight parking prohibition. Said permits shall not
be eligible for use in Village metered spaces, permit parking only spaces, or
in a drop-off zone for persons with disabilities.
   Employee permits where authorized by ordinance: One hundred twenty four
dollars ($124.00) per year.
   Student permits:
      If the Village administers permit sales:
         Residents: Two hundred forty dollars ($240.00) per year.
         Nonresidents: Three hundred twenty dollars ($320.00) per year.
      The daytime permit parking rate for all students shall be two hundred
forty dollars ($240.00) per year if the school attended by the students
purchases all student parking permits for students at that school for the full
year prior to August 31 annually and the school agrees to administer the
distribution of all such permits subject to the review of the Parking Services
Manager.
      Permits may be issued on a monthly or quarterly basis for an equivalent
portion of the annual fee subject to the Village's discretion.
      Fees which are not expended to cover the costs of administering the
daytime, on street, permit parking program shall be deposited in a fund
entitled the "Daytime Off Street Parking Fund", which shall be used exclusively
for the provision of additional daytime, off street parking.
   Any conflict between the provisions of this subsection and any other
ordinance establishing daytime on street permit parking in a specific area
within the Village shall be resolved in favor of the other ordinance.
   K.   On Street Overnight Permit Parking Fee In R-7 Zoned Districts:
      1.   One hundred thirty seven dollars ($137.00) per quarter for "high
demand areas", defined, for purposes of this subsection 15-3-18K, as parking
zones established by the Village Board that are more than eighty percent (80%)
full for four (4) consecutive quarters.
      2.   One hundred twenty seven dollars ($127.00) per quarter for "medium
demand areas", defined for purposes of this subsection 15-3-18K as parking
zones established by the Village Board that are between twenty percent (20%)
and eighty percent (80%) full for four (4) consecutive quarters.
      3.   One hundred seventeen dollars ($117.00) per quarter for "low demand
areas", defined, for purposes of this subsection 15-3-18K, as parking zones
established by the Village Board that are less than twenty percent (20%) full
for four (4) consecutive quarters.
   Any conflict between the provisions of this subsection and any other
ordinance establishing on-street overnight permit parking in R-7 Zoned
Districts within the Village shall be resolved in favor of this subsection.

   M.   Valet Permit Parking: Current valet parking license holders may apply
for valet parking permits in Village operated parking structures or lots
designated by the Village as available for valet parking.
      1.   The Village valet parking permit shall be in the form of a laminated
placard which may be transferred from valet parked vehicle to valet parked
vehicle.
      2.   The valet parking placard shall be displayed on the dashboard of the
valet parked vehicle at the location authorized by the valet permit.
      3.   The valet placard shall be eight and one-half inches by eleven
inches (81/2" x 11") in size and shall contain the name and current valet
license number of the business, the beginning and end dates of the quarter to
which it applies and the number of the lot in which valet permit parking has
been authorized.
      4.   The valet parking placard shall only authorize valet permit parking
on Thursday through Saturday evenings between six o'clock (6:00) P.M. and one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. during the quarter and in the lot designated by the
placard.
      5.   Valet parking permits shall only be issued to current valet license
holders and shall only be issued as the Village determines space is available
for same in a given Village operated parking structure or lot.
      6.   The Village shall charge a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per
quarter per valet parking placard.
      7.   Valet parking permit placards shall be sold on a first come, first
served basis although the Village may limit the number of valet permits per
valet parking license holder based upon the number of valet parking license
holders applying for valet parking permit placards in a given parking structure
or lot and the number of spaces available for same in a given structure or lot.
   N.   Reduced Parking Permit Fee Program: For permits to be issued on or
after April 1, 2023, eligible parking permit applicants shall be entitled to
pay a reduced fee as follows:
      1.   The registered owner of a vehicle for which a parking permit is
sought must be a current participant in the Oak Park Housing Authority’s
housing choice voucher program or a current resident or employee at one of the
following affordable housing locations in the Village:
         a.   Heritage House (201 Lake Street);
         b.   The 801 (801 Van Buren Street);
         c.   Grove Apartments (442 S. Grove Avenue);
         d.   The Oaks (114 S. Humphrey Avenue);
         e.   Farrelly-Muriello Apartments (435 S. Humphrey Avenue);
         f.   Mills Park Tower (1025 Pleasant Place);
         g.   The Wright Inn (211 N. Oak Park Avenue); and
         h.    An unhoused person residing at an emergency shelter location in
the Village and employees of an emergency shelter location in the Village. For
purposes of this section, an emergency shelter location is defined as a
building where persons are provided overnight sleeping accommodations for a
period not-to-exceed twelve (12) consecutive hours at a time.
      2.   The applicant must apply by submitting a form approved by the
Village’s Development Customer Services Director or the Director’s designee.
      3.   Reduced fee parking permits are subject to available spaces.
      4.   The reduced fee parking permit fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00)
per quarter for each eligible vehicle.
      5.   No fee shall be charged for those persons who meet the eligibility
requirements set forth in subsections (g) and (h) above.
   O.   Electric Vehicle Charging Station User Fee:
      1.   A fee of twenty-five cents ($0.25) per kilowatt-hour (kWh) of energy
dispensed shall be paid by a user of any of the Village's publicly-accessible
electric vehicle charging stations.
      2.   The user shall be responsible for payment of any applicable
convenience, transaction, processing or taxes that are assessed on the
transaction.
      3.   The Village shall determine the software and hardware by which the
fee is collected.
   P.   All parking charges herein shall be subject to any additional
applicable taxes unless otherwise set forth above. (Ord. 2010-0-74, 11-15-2010;
