ARTICLE 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
22-1-1: Hauling of Certain Materials Through Streets, Etc.
22-1-2: Injuring Pavement or Other Public Ground; Hindering Repair of Public
Improvements
22-1-3: Leaving Openings in Streets and Sidewalks
22-1-4: Curb Line Grade; Determined by Grade of Improved Street
22-1-5: Curb Line Grade; Intersecting Streets to Determine
22-1-6: Sidewalk Slope
22-1-7: Grades to Reference Datum Bench Mark
22-1-1: HAULING OF CERTAIN MATERIALS THROUGH STREETS, ETC.:
Any person who shall engage in hauling stone, dirt, mortar, cinders, rubbish or
other matter that may be likely to fall from the vehicle, shall see that the
vehicle box shall be tight so that none of such matter shall sift through such
box. Any articles falling from a vehicle shall be promptly removed from the
street by the driver.
Any person neglecting or refusing to remove such dirt, sand, cinders, rubbish
or other material from the street promptly shall be fined as provided in
Section
1-1-5 of this Code for obstruction of a public way without a permit. In
addition thereto the Director of Public Works shall cause such substance to be
removed at the expense of the party so neglecting or refusing, who shall be
liable to repay and refund to the Village the cost of removal, which cost shall
be collected and paid into the Village treasury.
22-1-2: INJURING PAVEMENT OR OTHER PUBLIC GROUND; HINDERING REPAIR OF PUBLIC
IMPROVEMENTS:
No person shall injure or tear up any pavement, sidewalk or crosswalk or any
part thereof, dig any hole, ditch or drain in, or remove any sod, stone, earth,
sand or gravel from any street, alley or public ground in the Village without
having first obtained written permission from the Director of Public Works. Nor
shall any person hinder or obstruct the making or repairing of any public
improvement or work ordered by the Board of Trustees or being done under lawful
authority for the Village. Such injury, digging or tearing up referred to above
shall be done only under the supervision of the Director of Public Works.
22-1-3: LEAVING OPENINGS IN STREETS AND SIDEWALKS:
No person shall keep or leave open any cellar door or grating of any vault on
any street or sidewalk or suffer the same to be left or kept open.
22-1-4: CURB LINE GRADE; DETERMINED BY GRADE OF IMPROVED STREET:
In all cases where the grade of any street or alley has not been established by
general ordinance, the grade of the curb of such improved street as established
by a local improvement ordinance for the paving of such street, shall be the
established grade of such street for all purposes. All grades will be
determined by the Director of Public Works.
22-1-5: CURB LINE GRADE; INTERSECTING STREETS TO DETERMINE:
In all cases of unimproved streets where grades have not been established by
general ordinance or by local improvement ordinance, the established grade of
the improved streets intersecting therewith shall be and are hereby declared to
be the established grades for such unimproved streets. All grades will be
determined by the Director of Public Works.
22-1-6: SIDEWALK SLOPE:
The upper edge of the sidewalk nearest the lot line shall be above the
established grade of the street measured on a slope of one-fourth of an inch to
the foot from the established grade at the top of the curb. The surface of the
sidewalk shall slope toward the curb at the rate of one-quarter of an inch to
the foot, except where pre-existing conditions require otherwise; provided that
in no case shall such elevation exceed six inches (6").
22-1-7: GRADES TO REFERENCE DATUM BENCH MARK:
All grades now or hereafter fixed shall have reference to all base or datum
plane and bench marks as established by the Department of Public Works. The
Department of Public Works shall keep a record of all bench marks.
ARTICLE 2
SIDEWALK AND DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION
SECTION:
Division A. Generally
22-2-1: Specifications; Exemption
22-2-2: Construction Permit Required
22-2-3: Permit Fees
22-2-4: Director Of Public Works To Supervise Work
22-2-5: Procedure When Work Is Done Improperly
22-2-6: Encroaching On Sidewalk Space
Division B. Contractors
22-2-7: License Required; Exception
22-2-8: Bond Or Insurance Certificate Required
DIVISION A. GENERALLY
22-2-1: SPECIFICATIONS; EXEMPTION:
All sidewalks and driveways which shall be constructed in the Village on public
property shall be of concrete and shall be constructed in all respects
according to the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction"
adopted by the department of transportation of the state of Illinois on January
1, 2012; copies to be maintained in the Department of Public Works.
It is further provided, however, that a different type of construction for
sidewalks and driveways shall be approved by the Director of Public Works
provided:
   A.   A plan of the sidewalk and/or driveway indicating the type of
construction is submitted to the Department of Public Works.
   B.   In the case of public sidewalk construction, at least two hundred feet
(200') of frontage is to be paved, except that this requirement may be waived
by the Board of Trustees where the Board finds it is in the public interest to
do so.
   C.   The owner indemnifies the Village against liability in connection with
the pavement, either by bond or insurance coverage with the Village named as a
party insured, said bond or insurance to be approved by the Law Department.
   D.   The owner agrees to assume any additional costs of maintenance,
including any costs to restore the material following public improvements made
along the public right of way.
   E.   Brick sidewalks shall be installed on an aggregate base of six inches
(6") together with a sand cushion of one inch (1"). An optional four inch (4")
concrete base may be substituted for the six inches (6") of aggregate base.
   F.   Brick driveways shall be constructed on an aggregate base of eight
inches (8") in thickness together with a sand cushion of one inch (1"). An
optional six inch (6") concrete base may be substituted for the eight inches
(8") of aggregate base.
   G.   A plan for permeable pavements for sidewalk and/or driveway
construction shall be submitted to the Department of Public Works and shall be
approved by the Director of Public Works. (Ord. 15-047, 2-2-2015)
22-2-2: CONSTRUCTION PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person desiring to lay down any sidewalk, curbing or driveway shall proceed
with such work until he has applied for and received a permit from the Director
of Public Works setting forth the necessary lines and grades. (1981 Code)
22-2-3: PERMIT FEES:
The terms and fees which shall be charged for the permit required by this
article and demanded in advance for the benefit of the Village from the owners
of property ordering the work to be performed, or against whom the work is
properly chargeable are as follows:
For locating and furnishing street, alley, sidewalk or curb line or grade for
any frontage, a one hundred dollar ($100.00) cash deposit or certified check
shall be deposited with the Village Clerk's office to ensure proper
restoration. (1981 Code)
22-2-4: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS TO SUPERVISE WORK:
It shall be the duty of the Director of Public Works, to superintend the
construction of sidewalks, so far as may be necessary to compel their
construction on the grade and line established and furnished by the Public
Works Department, and of the materials and in the manner prescribed in this
article or the particular ordinances and orders concerning such sidewalks and
of the material prescribed therefor. (1981 Code)
22-2-5: PROCEDURE WHEN WORK IS DONE IMPROPERLY:
If any person shall build, or attempt to build, any sidewalk or portion thereof
and fail, neglect or refuse in so doing, to comply with the provisions of this
article or the particular ordinance concerning such sidewalk, the Director of
Public Works shall direct such sidewalk, or portion thereof, as the case may
be, to be relaid. In case of the failure, neglect or refusal of the person so
directed to immediately comply with such direction, the Director shall require
the property owner, if any portion of such sidewalk has been laid, to remove
the same and to relay the same as provided by this article and in conformity
with any special requirement as in this division provided. Such persons may
also be punished as provided in section 1-1-5 of this code. (1981 Code)
22-2-6: ENCROACHING ON SIDEWALK SPACE:
No person shall erect or place any structure, in whole or in part, upon any
street, alley or sidewalk within the Village nor shall part of any sidewalk be
taken for private use, by lowering or cutting down the same next to the
structure or railing off the same by any wooden or iron railing or by shutting
off the public from passing along and over the same and such sidewalks shall
not be raised up next to the building by constructing a platform or platforms
on the same, of either wood, iron or stone, but such sidewalks shall be built
flush up to the building on a uniform grade, as herein provided. (1981 Code)
Where it is necessary to construct access ramps for the handicapped into a
building, said access ramp may extend onto the public sidewalk, provided said
ramp is protected by a sufficient wall, is adequately illuminated and provided
that the remaining portion of the walk not affected by the ramp is not less
than six feet (6') in width. Before a permit shall issue, the property owner
requesting such a ramp shall furnish the Village a covenant to indemnify the
Village from any claims arising from said encroachment and further covenanting
to maintain the ramp, the protective wall and illumination at the expense of
the property owner. The covenant shall be recorded and shall run with the land.
(Ord. 1980-0-26, 5-5-1980)
DIVISION B. CONTRACTORS
22-2-7: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTION:
No person shall engage in the business of constructing or repairing sidewalks
in any public street or place in the Village without first having obtained a
license therefor and furnishing a bond or insurance certificate as hereinafter
provided. (1981 Code)
22-2-8: BOND OR INSURANCE CERTIFICATE REQUIRED:
Every person licensed under the provisions of this article shall, before
commencing construction on any public way, deposit with the Village Clerk a
bond in the penal sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) with surety to be
approved by the Village Clerk and conditioned to indemnify, save and keep
harmless the Village from any and all loss, cost, expense or liability of any
kind whatsoever which the Village may suffer or be put to or which may be
recovered from it by reason of such construction license or by reason of any
act or thing done or neglected to be done under or by virtue of the authority
given in such license; or the contractor may include the Village as a party
insured under the contractor's general liability insurance policy in an amount
not less than two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00). (1981 Code)
ARTICLE 3
EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
22-3-1: Permit Required, Application
22-3-2: Permit Fee, Deposit
22-3-3: Bond or Insurance Policy Required
22-3-4: Restoration
22-3-5: Barricades Required
22-3-6: Failure to Restore
22-3-7: Return of Surplus Deposit, Deficiencies
22-3-8: Pavement Openings Moratorium And Restrictions
22-3-1: PERMIT REQUIRED, APPLICATION:
No person shall interfere with or affect a change in any public way or public
property in the Village without having first obtained a permit from the
Director of Public Works given in accordance with the provision of this Code or
other ordinances of the Village.
All applications for permits under this Article shall be accompanied by a plat
or pencil tracing or sketch showing the location, character and dimensions of
the proposed opening for the installation of new work or the location and
character of the alterations involving changes in the location of pipes,
conduits, wire or conductors. The application shall state the time, place and
character of such opening and the purpose thereof.
22-3-2: PERMIT FEE, DEPOSIT:
For each and every permit issued for an opening in any street there shall be
collected a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00).
Before a permit shall be granted to any person for interfering with or
affecting a change in any public way or public property in the Village a cash
deposit or certified check for one hundred dollars ($100.00) for restoration
purposes must be deposited with the Village Clerk.
If special circumstances exist, it is within the discretion of the Director of
Public Works to require a larger deposit to meet potential restoration costs.
22-3-3: BOND OR INSURANCE POLICY REQUIRED:
No permit shall be issued to any person permitting or allowing any interference
with or affecting any change in any public way or public property in the
Village, until the person making application for such permit shall first have
executed to the Village a good and sufficient bond in the amount of fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00), with sureties to be approved by the Corporation
Counsel, conditioned:
To indemnify, save and keep harmless the Village from any and all loss, cost,
damage, expense or liability of any kind whatsoever which the Village may
suffer or which may be recovered against the Village from or on account of the
issuance of the permit to obstruct, tear up, remove or repair any sidewalk,
parkway, street, alley or part thereof and from or on account of any act or
thing done by the permittee or permitted by the permittee in the obstruction,
tearing up, removing or repairing of any sidewalk, parkway, street alley or
part thereof.
In the event any proposed work may appear to subject the Village to the
possibility of any greater liability than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00),
the Corporation Counsel may require the amount of the bond to be increased to
an amount sufficient to protect the Village against any such loss, cost, damage
or expense.
The bond aforesaid shall not be required if an insurance policy in the minimum
amount of two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) covering public liability
and including the Village as a party insured is furnished.
22-3-4: RESTORATION:
   A.   Paved Roadways. The person interfering with or causing a change in any
public way or public property is responsible for restoration. If restoration is
not completed by such person within a reasonable time, the restoration
(including backfill, concrete replacement and asphalt patching) of any street
or paved alley shall be performed by the Village, the cost of such restoration
to be deducted from the deposit provided for in Section
22-3-2.
The restoration of the roadway of any street or paved alley will conform to the
following standards:
      1.   No excavated material shall be used for backfill except by the
written consent of the Director of Public Works or his authorized agent.
      2.   Backfill material shall consist of sand or stone screenings and
shall be deposited in six inch (6") layers, each layer to be suitably rammed or
tamped. Puddling of backfill material may be substituted for tamping.
      3.   All trenches or excavations made in any improved street or alley,
shall be refilled to a point on a level with the subgrade immediately below the
pavement with such care and in such a manner that there will be no further
settlement of the filling material. The replaced pavement above the subgrade
shall be identical with and correspond in every way to the original
improvement, except that in all cases where concrete is required Portland
cement shall be used.
      4.   All concrete used for this work shall be delivered from ready mix
trucks and shall conform to State highway specifications. The concrete shall
contain no more water than is required for a four inch (4") slump. After the
concrete has been laid, as above described, the same shall be protected from
traffic for one week and until the concrete is thoroughly set.
      5.   Before final restoration is made to concrete patches, the perimeter
of the concrete shall be cut back neatly and squarely at least twelve inches
(12") beyond the limits of the original excavation.
   B.   Parkways. All trenches or other excavations in any parkway shall be
refilled and the sod removed in making such trenches and excavations shall be
replaced or, after refilling the same, the surface shall be sowed with grass
seed or resodded as determined by the Director of Public Works and shall be
cared for until the same is restored to as good condition in every way as
before the excavations were made.
   C.   Sidewalks and Curbs. All damaged or removed sidewalks shall be replaced
with new five inch (5") thick squares equal in width of adjoining squares.
Where sidewalk replacements are required, only full squares may be placed.
Where curb and gutter sections are to be replaced, the repair must include all
the curb and gutter between joints, unless sawed joints are provided.
Any underground improvements of any kind which may be encountered in making
street excavations shall not be molested or disturbed in any way and if injured
shall be at once repaired and restored to their original condition without cost
to the owners thereof.
All the work herein before referred to shall be done in a good and workmanlike
manner and shall be maintained and kept in good order and repair until the
deposit aforesaid is refunded, but not to exceed one year. Each person shall
from time to time during such year repair or refill any such ditch, trench or
other excavation, if called upon so to do by the Director of Public Works or
other proper officer of the Village and all such work shall be done and
performed to the full and complete satisfaction of the Director of Public Works
or of such officer as may hereafter be appointed to perform the same or similar
duties as are now performed by such Director and to the full satisfaction of
and without expense to the Village.
22-3-5: BARRICADES REQUIRED:
It shall be the duty of every person engaged in digging into any street, in
paving any street, building any sewer or drain or trench for water pipes in any
of the public streets or avenues under contract with the Village, or by virtue
of any permission which may have been granted to them by the Board of Trustees,
or any Village department, where such work, if left exposed, would be
dangerous, to erect a fence, railing or barricade, and to place a suitable
covering where necessary as determined by the Director of Public Works, around
such excavations or work in such a manner as to prevent danger to persons who
may be traveling such streets, roads or avenues and to continue and uphold such
fence, railing or barricade until the work shall be completed or the
obstruction or danger removed. It shall also be the duty of such persons to
place upon such fence, railing or barricade at twilight in the evening suitable
and sufficient warning lights and keep them burning through the night during
the performance of such work, under the penalty as provided in Section
1-1-5 of this Code for every neglect. Flares, lanterns, "bombs" or other
devices using a flame shall not be permitted as suitable lights.
No person shall remove any barricade or light or other danger signal erected in
front of or about any defective sidewalk or street within the Village, or in
front of or about any sidewalk or street under repair or undergoing
reconstruction within the Village, or in any way interfere with, change or
destroy such barricade, light or other danger signal until such sidewalk or
street is repaired or rebuilt.
The provisions of the preceding section shall apply to every person who shall
place building materials in any of the public streets, avenues or public places
or be engaged in building any vault or constructing any lateral drain from any
cellar to any public sewer, or who shall do or perform any work causing
obstructions in the public streets by virtue of any permit from any executive
department and also to all public or Village officers engaged in performing any
work in behalf of the Village whereby obstructions or excavations shall be made
in the public streets.
The extent to which the railing or fence, or barricade referred to herein shall
be built is hereby defined in the following situations:
   A.   In digging into any street or road, by placing the same along the upper
bank of such excavation or by extending the fence so far across the street or
road as to prevent persons from traveling on such portions as would be
dangerous.
   B.   In paving any street or avenue, by extending the same across the
roadway of such street or avenue, or if but a portion of the width of such
roadway be obstructed, across such portion; in which case the obstruction shall
be so arranged as to leave a passageway through, as nearly as may be of uniform
width.
   C.   In the building of a sewer, by placing the same across the roadway at
the ends of such excavations as shall be made.
   D.   In building vaults, by enclosing the ground taken for the vaults.
   E.   In placing building material in the streets, by placing the same across
so much of the street as shall be occupied by such materials and the materials
shall be so placed as to occupy a space of uniform width.
   F.   In the construction or repair of any building, by placing the same
around so much of the public way as the Director of Public Works shall deem
necessary for the safety of the public.
22-3-6: FAILURE TO RESTORE:
In the event that any person opening any street, alley or public way, fails to
restore such street, alley or public way in the manner provided in this Article
within ten (10) days after written notice so to do has been mailed or served
upon such person, then and in such event the Director of Public Works shall
have such work done and the cost thereof shall be charged to the person to whom
the permit was issued, and shall be deducted from the amount deposited by such
person as required in Section 22-3-2.
22-3-7: RETURN OF SURPLUS DEPOSIT, DEFICIENCIES:
After completion of the work, under the provisions of this article, to the
satisfaction of the Director of Public Works, he shall certify to the Director
of Finance the amount of any surplus remaining from the amount deposited in
such case, and such surplus shall thereupon be paid over to the proper claimant
upon presentation to the Village Clerk of the deposit receipt; but if for any
reason the amount of such deposit shall have been insufficient to cover the
cost of such work, or if any damage shall have been done to any underground
work or connections, or otherwise, not contemplated in the original estimate,
which shall have caused increased expenditure, the amount of such deficiency or
damage shall be certified to the Director of Finance who shall collect the same
from the person to whom the permit was issued. (1981 Code)
22-3-8: PAVEMENT OPENINGS MORATORIUM AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Unless the Director of Public Works determines that circumstances
warrant the opening of pavement, no permit shall be issued for:
      1.   Opening any pavement that has been newly constructed or
reconstructed after January 1, 2020, for a period of five (5) years after the
completion of the construction or reconstruction of the pavement;
      2.   Opening any pavement that has been resurfaced after January 1, 2021,
within three (3) years after the completion date of the resurfaced pavement; or
      3.   Opening any pavement located in the DT Downtown Zoning District as
defined said district is defined in the Oak Park Zoning Ordinance, as amended,
between the Thanksgiving holiday in any given year and January 1 of the
following year.
   B.   When determining whether circumstances warrant the opening of pavement
pursuant to this section, the Director of Public Works shall consider whether
the proposed work for the opening constitutes an emergency and will provide a
public benefit. In addition, the Director shall consider whether there is no
other reasonable access to perform the opening and other reasonable factors in
the Director's discretion. (Ord. 21-27, 2-22-2021)
ARTICLE 4
OBSTRUCTION OF AND ENCROACHMENTS UPON PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
22-4-1: Public Ways To Be Kept Clear; Exception; Regulation Of Public
Assemblies In Streets
22-4-2: Games, Exhibitions, Assemblies Prohibited; Roller Skates, Skateboards,
Bicycles Regulated
22-4-3: Owner To Remove Street Obstructions; Procedure For Failure To Remove
22-4-4: Encumbering Public Ways Without Permission
22-4-5: Procedure For Selling Articles Removed From Streets
22-4-6: Storage On Public Ways
22-4-7: Leaving Goods On Sidewalks During Delivery
22-4-8: Persons Required To Remove Snow And Ice From Public Sidewalks Fronting
Or Abutting Parcels Or Lots Owned, Occupied, Leased Or Otherwise Controlled By
Them Within The Village
22-4-1: PUBLIC WAYS TO BE KEPT CLEAR; EXCEPTION; REGULATION OF PUBLIC
ASSEMBLIES IN STREETS:
The streets, avenues, alleys and sidewalks in the Village shall be kept free
and clear at all times of all encumbrances and encroachments except as may be
herein or by ordinance or resolution of the Village otherwise specially
provided. No person shall, at any time, congregate or assemble in or upon any
of the public streets, avenues, alleys or sidewalks of the Village in such a
manner as to obstruct or interfere with the passage of vehicles in and along
such streets, avenues or alleys or the passage of persons along the streets and
sidewalks or in such a manner as to disturb or threaten the public peace. Any
person in such assembly who fails or refuses, upon the order of any police
officer of the Village to move on or away from such assembly, shall be punished
as provided in section
1-1-5 of this Code. (1981 Code)
22-4-2: GAMES, EXHIBITIONS, ASSEMBLIES PROHIBITED; ROLLER SKATES, SKATEBOARDS,
BICYCLES REGULATED:
No person shall engage in any game, sport, amusement or business, or exhibit
any machine, show or animal, or indulge in any acrobatic feats or anything else
in the streets or upon the sidewalks which shall collect any crowd of persons
so as to interfere with the passage of vehicles or persons passing along the
streets and sidewalks.
Nor shall any person by means of any sport, game, amusement or exhibition, or
by exhortation or otherwise, induce or attempt to induce the congregating or
assembling of persons in or upon any of the public streets, avenues, alleys or
sidewalks of the Village, whereby the passage of vehicles in and along such
streets or the passage of persons along such streets or sidewalks is obstructed
or interfered with or whereby the public peace is threatened or disturbed.
   A.   Roller Skates, Skateboards And Bicycles Regulated: No person shall
rollerskate or ride a skateboard or bicycle anywhere in the Village without
complying with the terms and provisions of this section.
      1.   Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply:
   BUSINESS OR COMMERCIAL DISTRICT: Any areas of the Village in which business
or commercial activities are conducted and which are zoned B-1, B-2, B-3, B-
4 or C as set forth on the Zoning Map of the Village. A map of the Village
designating the business and commercial districts is shown in Exhibit 22-4-2A1
of this article.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/939533cf0e4682a2aa68b2d78fc3bca5e1eb689b/
IMAGES/0-0-0-3320.gif]
   ROLLERSKATE: To skate on any type of roller skates or street skates.
   SKATEBOARD: A board of any material to which roller skate wheels or similar
wheels are attached.
   STREET: Every way or place which is open to the use of the public as a
matter of right for purposes of general vehicular traffic circulation.
      2.   Streets: No person shall rollerskate, or use or ride a skateboard on
any street except for the purpose of crossing the street. All laws and
regulations relating to pedestrians crossing streets shall apply to persons
crossing a street on roller skates or a skateboard.
      3.   Sidewalks: No person shall rollerskate or ride a skateboard in a
reckless manner on any public sidewalk. Persons riding a skateboard or
rollerskating on a public sidewalk shall exercise due care for the safety of
other persons using the sidewalk and shall yield the right of way to
pedestrians using such sidewalks at all times.
      4.   Village Property And Business And Commercial Districts: No person
shall use or ride a skateboard, rollerskate or ride a bicycle in any Village
public parking garage or lot, in the Village Hall inner courtyard or upon any
sidewalk, alley or other pedestrian public way in any business or commercial
district within the Village.
      5.   Sales And Rentals: Any commercial establishment selling or renting
skateboards or roller skates of any kind shall post a copy of this section, or
a summary of the rules set out in this section in a conspicuous place where
persons buying or renting skates or skateboards will see it. (Ord. 1990-0-5, 2-
20-90)
22-4-3: OWNER TO REMOVE STREET OBSTRUCTIONS; PROCEDURE FOR FAILURE TO REMOVE:
The owner of any building, fence, porch, steps, gallery or other obstruction
now standing or which may hereafter be erected or placed upon any street, alley
or sidewalk or public ground within the Village, or which may be left standing
upon any new street that has been or may hereafter be opened, shall remove the
same within such reasonable time, not exceeding thirty (30) days, as he shall
be required so to do by a notice signed by the Director of Public Works.
Whenever the owner of any such building, fence or other obstruction shall
refuse or neglect to remove the same after notice, or if the owner cannot be
readily found for the purpose of such notice, the same shall be deemed a
nuisance, and it shall be lawful for the Director of Public Works to cause the
same to be removed or taken down in his discretion, and the expense thereof
shall be recoverable from the owner. Every person who shall oppose or resist
the execution of the orders of the Director in the premises shall be punished
as provided in section
1-1-5 of this code. (1981 Code)
22-4-4: ENCUMBERING PUBLIC WAYS WITHOUT PERMISSION:
No person shall encumber or obstruct or cause to be encumbered or obstructed,
any street, alley or other public place in the Village, by placing therein or
thereon any building material or any article or thing whatsoever, without
having first obtained written permission for the Director of Public Works.
The Director of Public Works or any officer of the Village is authorized to
cause any obstruction, encroachment or other thing, which may be in violation
of the provisions of this article to be removed within a reasonable time after
notice served upon the owner, agent or person in possession of the premises
where such violation occurs; or in case the owner, agent or person in
possession cannot be found, then summarily to remove the same, and the owner,
agent or party causing such violation, shall pay all expenses and costs of such
removal. Any person who shall wrongfully interfere with such removal shall be
punished as provided in section
1-1-5 of this code. (1981 Code)
22-4-5: PROCEDURE FOR SELLING ARTICLES REMOVED FROM STREETS:
Any article or thing which may be removed in accordance with the preceding
section, if of sufficient value to more than pay the expense thereof, shall be
advertised in any newspaper circulated in the Village for ten (10) days and
sold by the Director of Public Works unless the same shall be sooner reclaimed
and the penalty and costs paid by the owners thereof. The proceeds of such sale
shall be paid into the Village treasury and the balance, if any after deducting
penalty and costs, shall be paid to any person furnishing satisfactory proof of
ownership. (1981 Code)
22-4-6: STORAGE ON PUBLIC WAYS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or store on any public way or
public property, building materials or any fuels or any goods, wares, supplies
or merchandise, or sign of any kind or description whatever. (1981 Code)
22-4-7: LEAVING GOODS ON SIDEWALKS DURING DELIVERY:
No person shall, while receiving or delivering goods, wares or merchandise,
permit the same to remain on any sidewalk or in any street longer than two (2)
hours, and for this purpose he shall occupy only so much of the outer edge of
the sidewalk in front of his store or building as will leave an unoccupied
space of four feet (4') in width of such sidewalk free from skids and
obstructions of every character for the use of pedestrians. (1981 Code)
22-4-8: PERSONS REQUIRED TO REMOVE SNOW AND ICE FROM PUBLIC SIDEWALKS FRONTING
OR ABUTTING PARCELS OR LOTS OWNED, OCCUPIED, LEASED OR OTHERWISE CONTROLLED BY
THEM WITHIN THE VILLAGE:
   A.   The owner, occupant, lessee or person otherwise legally in possession
and/or control of any lot or parcel in the Village shall remove and clear away,
or cause to be removed or cleared away, all snow and ice on the public sidewalk
fronting or abutting any such lot or parcel.
   B.   Snow and ice shall be removed within twenty four (24) hours after the
cessation of any fall of snow, sleet, or freezing rain; provided, however, in
the event snow and ice on a sidewalk has become so hard that it cannot
reasonably be removed without damaging the sidewalk, the person or entity
charged with its removal, herein, shall, within the twenty four (24) hour time
period, cause a reasonable amount of sand, salt or other abrasive material to
be placed upon the entire sidewalk in order to make pedestrian travel thereon
reasonably safe; and as soon thereafter as weather permits, said person or
entity shall effect the removal of snow and ice as provided herein.
   C.   The fine for the violation of the requirements set forth in this
section shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) if paid within fourteen (14) days
after the date of the notice of the violation. If the fine is not paid within
fourteen (14) days of the date of the notice of violation, an additional
penalty of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be imposed. (Ord. 2010-0-93, 11-22-
2010)
ARTICLE 5
PRIVATE DRIVEWAYS
SECTION:
22-5-1: Permit - Prerequisite to Construction; Nonassignable
22-5-2: Permit - Application
22-5-3: Permit - Fees
22-5-4: Permit - Revocation
22-5-5: Bond Required
22-5-6: Deposit Prerequisite to Commencing Construction; Duty to Restore
Street; Restoration After Default
22-5-7: Use of Driveway Without Permit
22-5-8: Driveways in Certain Residential Zoned Districts
22-5-9: Driveway and Sidewalk to be Kept Clear
22-5-10: Parking Space, Paving
22-5-1: PERMIT - PREREQUISITE TO CONSTRUCTION; NONASSIGNABLE:
No person shall hereafter build, construct, maintain or use any driveway
leading from a public street into abutting property or disturb the sidewalk or
make an opening in any street or other public property for the purpose of
constructing or maintaining a driveway without first obtaining a permit so to
do from the Director of Public Works.
No such permit shall be issued except as hereinafter provided, and no such
permit shall be transferred or assigned, nor shall any right or privilege
thereunder be transferred or assigned except as hereinafter provided.
22-5-2: PERMIT - APPLICATION:
Application for a permit for a driveway shall be made to the Director of Public
Works and shall contain the name and address of the person by whom such
driveway is to be used or maintained and the proposed location and dimensions
of such driveway. Plans and specifications of such driveway shall be filed with
the Director of Public Works. All plans and specifications shall conform to the
standard plan and specifications and requirements for a driveway leading from a
public street into abutting property on file in the office of the Director of
Public Works.
22-5-3: PERMIT - FEES:
The permit fee to be charged for the construction of each driveway entrance
shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00). Where a driveway is constructed or
maintained leading from a public street into abutting property within a
business, commercial or light industrial district as described and included in
the Zoning Ordinance, or any of the amendments thereof, and wherever the width
of the driveway entrance or entrances shall exceed twenty five feet (25'),
there shall be paid to the Village an annual permit fee of three dollars
($3.00) per lineal foot of width of driveway in excess of twenty five feet
(25'). The width on which the permit fee shall be charged shall be the width of
the driveway at the property line.
22-5-4: PERMIT - REVOCATION:
Permits issued under this Article shall contain conditions providing as
follows: The same may be revoked by the Board of Trustees at any time without
the consent of the grantee, in which case the authority and privileges granted
shall thereupon cease and terminate. Upon the termination by revocation,
expiration or otherwise of the authority, rights and privileges granted by such
permit, the driveway therein authorized shall be removed and the street space
where the same shall have been located shall be restored to its proper
condition to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Works so that the
portion of the street space used for such driveway shall be safe for public use
and in the same condition as the remaining portion of such street and such
sidewalk space, at the sole expense of the grantee therein, without cost or
expense of any kind whatsoever to the Village; provided, that in the event of
the failure, neglect or refusal on the part of such grantee to remove and
restore such driveway when directed so to do, the Village may proceed to remove
and restore the same and charge the expense thereof to such grantee.
The issuance of the driveway permit is conditioned upon the continued
maintenance of the driveway in good condition and repair. If this condition is
not adhered to the driveway permit may be revoked.
22-5-5: BOND REQUIRED:
All applicants for a permit for a driveway leading from a public street into
abutting property within any commercial district or industrial district, shall
give a bond in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with sureties
to be approved by the Director of Public Works. Such bond shall be conditioned
among other things, that such permission and authority to construct such
driveway shall be subject to modifications or revocation by the Director of
Public Works without the consent of the applicant; that the applicant shall
indemnify and save harmless the Village from all liability for damages or
expense resulting from or by reason of the granting of such permission or by
reason of any act or thing done by the applicant by virtue of the permission
herein provided for and further conditioned for the prompt vacation of such
driveway upon thirty (30) days' notice from the Director of Public Works,
whenever in the opinion of the Director of Public Works, it shall be necessary
or advisable to have such driveway space or any portion thereof, vacated in
order to provide for the use of such driveway space or any portion thereof for
a public purpose; and conditioned further that upon termination by revocation,
expiration or otherwise of the authority, rights and privileges granted by such
permit, the driveway therein authorized shall be removed and the street
pavement, curbing, parkway and sidewalk space, where the same shall have been
located, shall be restored to its proper condition to the satisfaction of the
Director of Public Works, so that the portion of the street used for such
driveway shall be safe for public use and in the same condition as the
remaining portion of such street at the sole expense of the grantee therein
without cost or expense of any kind whatsoever to the Village.
22-5-6: DEPOSIT PREREQUISITE TO COMMENCING CONSTRUCTION; DUTY TO RESTORE
STREET; RESTORATION AFTER DEFAULT:
No person shall construct a driveway unless the applicant therefor has
deposited with the Village Clerk's office a sum of one hundred dollars
($100.00) in cash or by a certified check or a larger sum of money sufficient
in the judgment of the Director of Public Works to defray the cost and expense
of restoration once work is completed. Every such applicant disturbing any
street for the purpose of constructing a driveway shall, within ten (10) days
after so disturbing it, restore the same to such a condition as will meet the
approval of the Director of Public Works. When such street is so restored by
such applicant, the sum so paid shall be refunded after approval of the
Director of Public Works to such applicant. If such applicant shall fail to so
restore the premises including but not limited to street pavement or sidewalk
or any sewer, water pipe, street lighting cable or conduit to the proper
condition within ten (10) days after the same is disturbed by him, then the
Director of Public Works shall cause the same to be restored in a manner to
meet his approval and the cost thereof shall be paid out of such deposited sum.
22-5-7: USE OF DRIVEWAY WITHOUT PERMIT:
If any person now using or maintaining a driveway leading from a public street
into abutting property shall fail to take out a permit for such use as herein
provided, then the Director of Public Works shall proceed to remove such
driveway and close the opening in connection therewith at the owner's expense.
22-5-8: DRIVEWAYS IN CERTAIN RESIDENTIAL ZONED DISTRICTS:
No driveway shall be installed leading from a public street to any private
property in a single or two (2) family zoned district unless such driveway
serves as an ingress leading to a legal parking space (as defined in the
Village Zoning Ordinance) located on such private property. (1981 Code)
22-5-9: DRIVEWAY AND SIDEWALK TO BE KEPT CLEAR:
No vehicle parked on a parkway crossing driveway shall be parked in such a
manner so as to extend beyond the curb line of the street or block public
sidewalk.
Where a driveway is permitted at or near street intersections, where such
streets have been established as through streets, boulevards or stop
intersections, no driveway shall be used by vehicles as a means to avoid
observance of the regulations that all vehicles must come to a complete stop
before entering a through street, boulevard or stop intersection.
No use shall be made of any driveway except in connection with the use of the
abutting property. (Ord. 1993-0-28, 4-19-93)
22-5-10: PARKING SPACE; PAVING:
No motor vehicle shall be parked on any unenclosed parking space having a
capacity of four (4) automobiles or less established on any lot where the
principal building is constructed after October 29, 1969 unless such space
shall meet the following structural minimal requirements:
   A.   Flexible Pavement: An eight inch (8") macadam base course or other
materials of the required thickness to obtain the same structural equivalents
and a two inch (2") surface course consisting of bituminous brand mix
materials, or;
   B.   Rigid Pavement: Six inch (6") Portland cement concrete pavement
constructed in accordance with recommendations published by the Portland Cement
Association.
All materials and construction procedures shall be in conformance with the
specifications provided in the standard specifications for road and bridge
construction adopted by the Department of Public Works and Buildings, Division
of Highways, State of Illinois, for pavements constructed in accordance with
subsection A of this Section.
Three (3) copies of the specifications adopted herein by reference are on file
in the office of the Village Clerk in accordance with provisions of the
Illinois Municipal Code.
ARTICLE 6
UNDERGROUND CONSTRUCTION AND USE
SECTION:
22-6-1: Permit - Required; Exception
22-6-2: Permit - Application
22-6-3: Permit - Bond Required
22-6-4: Permit - Fees
22-6-5: Permit - Agreement to Accompany Application
22-6-6: Permit - Issuance; Refusal
22-6-7: Permit - Cancellation of Permits Issued Under Terms of Prior Ordinances
22-6-8: Limitations on Use of Subspace - Generally
22-6-9: Limitations on Use of Subspace - Uses Prohibited
22-6-10: Limitations on Use of Subspace - Special Consent Required; Restoration
Deposit Required
22-6-11: Rights Reserved by Village
22-6-12: Failure to Procure Permit
22-6-13: Construction Specifications
22-6-14: Time Limit for Completing Work
22-6-15: Notice to Public Utility Companies
22-6-16: Protection of Openings - Generally
22-6-17: Protection of Openings - During Construction
22-6-18: Police Reports of Unsafe Openings
22-6-19: Unsafe Opening
22-6-20: Records and Inspection
22-6-21: Notice by Code Enforcement Director of Subsurface Areas in Use or
Intended to be Used; Notification to Users of Provisions of this Article
22-6-22: Certificate of Survey of Subsurface Area, Etc.
22-6-1: PERMIT - REQUIRED; EXCEPTION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any space under the surface of any
street, alley or other public place, or to cause or require any vault or other
structure to be constructed or made in any street, alley or other public place
except in that portion of the street, alley or other public place abutting the
property owned or occupied by him and except in connection with the use of such
property, without first having obtained and paid for and having in full force
and effect a permit therefor as hereinafter provided. The provisions of this
Article shall apply to any space underneath the surface of any street or other
public ground that may heretofore have been or may hereafter be used and to any
structures that have heretofore been or may hereafter be constructed.
22-6-2: PERMIT - APPLICATION:
Any person desiring to procure a permit for the use of any space underneath the
surface of any street or other public ground shall make and sign a written
application to the Director of Public Works upon forms provided by the Village
at least one week before starting the excavation. Such application shall give
the name and address of the applicant, the location of the existing or proposed
vault or the existing or proposed space underneath the surface of the street or
other public ground or any structure therein, the use made or intended to be
made thereof, the nature of all fixtures, machinery and appliances therein or
to be placed therein, and such other information as the Director of Public
Works may require. The application shall be accompanied by plans showing the
locations and dimensions of the existing or proposed vault or the existing or
proposed space underneath the surface of the street or other public ground or
any structure therein, the number, size and location of all existing or
proposed openings therein from the street, the method or proposed method for
protecting such openings, the character of the existing or proposed
construction, and the existing or proposed method of draining the space
underneath the surface of the street or other public ground.
The Director of Public Works shall immediately upon receipt thereof refer such
application and plans to the Building and Zoning Director for his action.
22-6-3: PERMIT - BOND REQUIRED:
The application required by the preceding section shall be accompanied by a
bond in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), approved as to
sufficiency by the Director of Public Works and as to form by the Corporation
Counsel and conditioned that the person to whom such permit shall be issued,
his heirs, successors or assigns, will save and keep harmless from any and all
losses or damages or claims of damages arising from or out of the use of the
space or structure therein mentioned and for the maintenance of the street,
alley or other public place or the sidewalk over such space, as the case may
be, in such condition that such street, alley or other public place or the
sidewalk shall be at all times after such structure is completed, or such space
is covered, safe for public use and for the full and complete protection of the
Village against any and all litigation growing out of the granting of such
permit or anything done under such permit and for the prompt and full payment
of all compensation or permit fees hereunder required, during his ownership or
possession of such property, so long as such permit shall be in force and for
the faithful performance and observance of all of the terms and conditions of
this Article. Whenever the Director of Public Works shall be of the opinion
that the sureties on any bond have become insufficient a new bond for such
permit shall thereupon be filed with sureties to be approved by the Director of
Public Works and the Corporation Counsel. Any person to whom a permit shall
have been granted, who shall convey the property to which such permit applies,
in fee, may notify the Director of Public Works, in writing, of the conveyance
in fee of such property and furnish the Director of Public Works, in writing,
the name and address of the purchaser thereof. Upon the giving of such notice,
in writing, and furnishing the name and address of such purchaser, such person
may procure from the Director of Public Works a permit to close up the space
being used underneath the surface of the street or other public ground in a
manner similar to the balance of the street, sidewalk or other public ground in
front of such premises and upon completion of such work to the satisfaction of
the Director of Public Works, all liability under the bond theretofore given by
such owner shall cease and determine, except as to the acts happening or causes
of action accruing prior to the completion of the work of closing such space to
the satisfaction of such Director. If, however, such purchaser shall pay a
transfer fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) and shall execute a new bond
conditioned as aforesaid and sign an agreement as provided herein, a renewal
permit shall be issued to such purchaser covering and applying to the same
vault or space specified in the original permit and it shall not be necessary
for the person to whom the original permit was issued to close up such opening,
but the filing of the bond and agreement and securing of a new permit by the
purchaser shall act as a release of liability under the bond originally given,
except as to causes of action accruing prior to the filing of such new bond.
The bond required in this Section shall be renewed and maintained, until such
time as the use of the space beneath the streets has terminated and the area is
restored to its original condition.
The permittee in lieu of the bond aforesaid, may furnish the Village a
certificate of insurance showing the Village included as a party insured in an
amount of not less than two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00), insuring
the Village from all losses, damages or claims arising out of the use of the
space designated, and a covenant running with the land agreeing to restore the
street or area when use of the vault is terminated.
22-6-4: PERMIT - FEES:
The fee to be charged for permits issued under this Article, by the Director of
Public Works, shall be based upon the number of square feet occupied by the
vault, space or structure under the surface of the sidewalk street or other
public ground, for which such permits are given. A fee of seven dollars fifty
cents ($7.50) will be charged for any space not exceeding one hundred (100)
square feet in area and an additional fifteen cents ($.15) per square foot will
be charged for each square foot in excess of one hundred (100) square feet or
fraction thereof.
Where the party to whom the original permit has been issued has transferred his
interest to another party, as hereinabove provided, the purchaser or transferee
of such interest shall pay the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) as the fee for
the issuance of a renewal permit.
All payments hereunder shall be due on the first day of January of each year
and shall expire on the thirty first day of December following the date of
issuance and when issued for a period of less than one year the fee to be paid
shall be a proportionate part of the fee fixed by this Section; provided, that
no fee shall be less than one-third (1/3) of the annual fee.
22-6-5: PERMIT - AGREEMENT TO ACCOMPANY APPLICATION:
The application referred to in Section
22-6-2 of this Code shall be accompanied by a written agreement upon a blank
form provided by the Village and signed by the owner of the abutting property,
that he, his heirs, successors and assigns shall permit the use of such space
underneath the surface of the street or other public ground as set forth in
this Article, hold the Village harmless from any claims for damages to himself
or the occupants of such estate resulting from gas, sewage or water leaking
into such excavation, release, relinquish, vacate and remove without cost to
the Village all machinery, fixtures and structural parts of or in such vault or
space underneath the surface of the street or other public ground within thirty
(30) days after having been ordered in writing to do so by the Director of
Public Works or after the revocation of the permit notwithstanding payment of
rent or fee, that in case of failure to comply with the written order of the
Director of Public Works within the time specified the Director of Public Works
may cause the same to be done and all expenses incurred or damages paid by the
Village on account thereof shall be paid by the person to whom the permit is
granted to the Village upon demand, that the Village may at any time enter upon
the premises for inspection and proper maintenance of anything therein, and
that the permit is granted with the understanding that the occupancy and use of
such space underneath the sidewalk by the applicant, his heirs, successors and
assigns is merely an accommodation and no right, title or interest of the
public is in any way waived or abridged thereby.
22-6-6: PERMIT - ISSUANCE; REFUSAL:
Upon the filing of the application, bond and agreement as required in this
Article, and upon the review of the application and plans by the Building and
Zoning Director, the Director of Public Works may, upon his approval of the
application and agreement and the payment to the Village of the fee required by
Section
22-6-4 of this Code, issue to the applicant a permit for one year. All permits
shall state clearly the location and size of the space underneath the surface
of the street or other public ground, the dates of issuance and expiration of
the permit, the fee paid and the name and address of the person to whom the
permit is issued. Permits shall be consecutively numbered, nontransferable and
nonassignable and revocable by the Director of Public Works upon thirty (30)
days' notice at any time he shall deem revocation advisable for the protection
of the Village's interest or the safety of the public or for a violation of the
provisions of this Article or any order issued pursuant thereto.
A refusal of a permit by the Director of Public Works shall be reviewed by the
Board of Trustees at the request of the applicant.
22-6-7: PERMIT - CANCELLATION OF PERMITS ISSUED UNDER TERMS OF PRIOR
ORDINANCES:
Whenever any person holding a permit for the construction or maintenance or use
of any vault or space underneath the surface of the street or other public
ground, which shall have been issued or made under the terms of any ordinance
or legal order heretofore in force, the conditions of which have been and are
now being fully complied with, shall apply for a permit under the provisions of
this Article and shall desire to have the permit or contract heretofore entered
into cancelled, the Director of Public Works shall cancel the same as regards
any liability thereunder arising after the date of the issuance of the new
permit hereunder, but such contract or permit and the bond given therewith
shall remain in full force and effect as to all rights and liabilities accruing
under the same, including all amounts due the Village for fees or compensation
under the same, up to the time of such cancellation.
22-6-8: LIMITATIONS ON USE OF SUBSPACE - GENERALLY:
No person shall hereafter erect or build or cause or permit any vault or space
to be made under an alley or entrance to an alley from the street or which
shall extend further than the line of the sidewalk or curbstone of any street.
22-6-9: LIMITATIONS ON USE OF SUBSPACE - USES PROHIBITED:
Boilers or other heating appliances, gasoline, gas or steam engines, pumps and
plumbing fixtures, gasoline, petroleum or gas storage tanks, flammable or
combustible materials or any pipe or fixture generating or emitting gas, steam
or offensive odors shall not be located or permitted in any space underneath
the surface of the street or other public ground. No fans or pipes ejecting
vitiated or superheated air from the adjoining building or exhaust pipe causing
disagreeable noise shall be located in or open into a space underneath the
surface of the street or other public ground.
22-6-10: LIMITATIONS ON USE OF SUBSPACE - SPECIAL CONSENT REQUIRED; RESTORATION
DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
No vault or space underneath the surface of any street or other public ground
shall be constructed so as to interfere with any sewer or water pipe, fire
hydrant, manhole, gas pipe, trees, lampost, street lighting cable or conduit,
or other public work or improvements nor with any electrical conduit carrying
fire alarm or police wires, unless by the written consent of the Director of
Public Works specially granted therefor, and no such consent shall be granted
until the applicant therefor has paid to the Director of Public Works a sum of
money sufficient in his judgment to defray the cost and expense of removing,
rebuilding, relaying or replacing such existing underground facility or
appurtenance. Every such applicant disturbing any such public work or
improvement enumerated above shall, within ten (10) days after so disturbing
it, restore the same to such a condition as will meet the approval of the
Director of Public Works. When such public work or improvement is so restored
by such applicant, the sum so paid to the Director of Public Works shall be
refunded by him to such applicant. If the applicant shall fail to restore such
public work or improvement within the time prescribed, the Director of Public
Works shall cause the work to be done and the cost thereof shall be paid out of
the sum deposited by the applicant and the balance, if any, refunded.
22-6-11: RIGHTS RESERVED BY VILLAGE:
The Village in granting a permit for a vault or space underneath the surface of
the street or other public ground reserves the right at any time to construct
and maintain under, over or through such vault or space, water or gas pipes,
drains, conduits for electric heat or power, sewers or other pipes, street
lighting cables or conduits or underground work needed for the public service
that the Director of Public Works may deem necessary to be placed in, below,
over or through the space occupied by the vault or space underneath the surface
of the street or other public ground, without compensation.
22-6-12: FAILURE TO PROCURE PERMIT:
Any person now using space underneath any sidewalk or other public place or any
person constructing or commencing the construction of a vault or the use of
space underneath the surface of the street or other public ground, who fails to
procure a permit as herein provided, shall, in addition to the other penalties
imposed by this Article, be required by the Director of Public Works to remove
every such structure and restore the ground to its original condition within
thirty (30) days after the service upon him of a written notice so to do. In
default, thereof, the Director of Public Works shall perform the work and the
costs shall constitute a debt of such owner to the Village, the same to be
recovered in a civil action.
22-6-13: CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS:
All vaults or space underneath the surface of any street or other public place
or any structure therein and their coverings, sidewalk lifts and openings in
sidewalks, shall be constructed in accordance with the plans, prepared, signed
and sealed by a registered structural engineer and approved by the Director of
Public Works.
   A.   All vaults or space underneath the surface of any street or other
public ground shall be enclosed with a sufficient concrete, stone or brick wall
or brick arches between iron or steel beams to retain the roadway of the
street, and the side, end or party walls of any building which shall extend
under the sidewalk, shall be of sufficient thickness to sustain such enclosing
walls or arch.
   B.   All vaults or space underneath the surface of any street or other
public ground shall be covered with a safe and substantial noncombustible
cover, and such covering shall be flush and level and kept flush and level with
the sidewalk. When a vault or space underneath the surface of any street or
other public place is covered with glass in iron or concrete frames, such glass
shall not be more than four inches (4") square each and the top surface of the
same shall be rough and graded in such a manner as to be entirely safe for
pedestrians. Such glass shall be kept in good repair at all times. Floor lights
when used in sidewalks shall not exceed one-third (1/3) of the width of the
sidewalk perpendicular to the curb.
   C.   The aperture or opening in the sidewalk over a vault or space shall be
covered with a strong glass or substantial iron or steel plate and frame with a
second top surface and rabbeted flush with the sidewalk. The dimensions of the
door in any direction shall not exceed the dimensions of the opening by more
than six inches (6"). All covers shall be subject to the approval of the
Director of Public Works. When any such cover is placed in any sidewalk, it
shall be placed as near as practicable to the outside line of the curb and
shall not exceed in area one-half (1/2) the width of the sidewalk. There shall
not be more than one opening for each twenty five feet (25') of street frontage
of any building and such openings shall not be closer than fifteen feet (15')
to each other.
   D.   All vaults or space underneath the surface of any street or other
public ground shall be thoroughly ventilated, properly drained and paved.
   E.   No open gratings or openings of a similar kind shall hereafter be
installed in the sidewalk for the purpose of obtaining light or ventilation or
for any other purpose.
   F.   When a hydrant bend exists in connection with a vault or space
underneath the surface of any street or other public ground, it shall be
protected by a brick wall not less than eight inches (8") in thickness, built
from the bottom of the basement to the underside of the sidewalk, which shall
be covered on both sides with plaster so as to be watertight or shall have
other protection of equal value.
   G.   The sidewalk over a vault or space shall be laid according to the
sidewalk specifications as provided in this Code for sidewalks on solid ground.
Where an open space is to be covered by a sidewalk, the Director of Public
Works shall require proper protection and reinforcement of such sidewalk.
Whenever the grade is changed, the top surface of any vault or space underneath
the surface of the street or other public ground must be changed and repaved at
the expense of the owner of the abutting property.
22-6-14: TIME LIMIT FOR COMPLETING WORK:
All vaults or space underneath the surface of the street or other public ground
shall be completed and the ground closed over them within thirty (30) days
after their construction has been commenced, unless an extension of time shall
be granted by the Director of Public Works.
22-6-15: NOTICE TO PUBLIC UTILITY COMPANIES:
Owners of abutting property shall notify the public utility companies concerned
at the time of construction when the removal or relocation of any underground
construction is made necessary by the construction of a vault or space
underneath the surface of the street or other public ground.
22-6-16: PROTECTION OF OPENINGS - GENERALLY:
No person shall remove or insecurely fix, or cause, procure, suffer or permit
to be removed or insecurely fixed, so that the same can be moved in its bed,
any covering over any such space, but nothing contained in this Article shall
prevent the owner or occupant of the building with which such space shall be
connected from removing the covering for the purpose of using such space;
provided, that he encloses such opening or aperture in a reasonably safe
manner, subject to approval by the Director of Public Works, and keeps the same
enclosed while such covering shall be removed; provided further, that he shall
not remove such covering until after sunrise of any day and shall replace it
before one-half (1/2) hour after sunset. Such space openings shall be kept
closed when not in use.
22-6-17: PROTECTION OF OPENINGS - DURING CONSTRUCTION:
During construction the owner of any building before which a vault or space
under the surface is being constructed or provided and every person having
charge of such work during the whole of the time such vault or space is opened
during the construction period shall cause the same to be guarded and enclosed
in a reasonably safe manner, subject to approval by the Director of Public
Works, and at night he shall cause a lighted lamp to be placed and kept thereon
in such a manner as to cast a light upon such vault or steps during the whole
of every night.
22-6-18: POLICE REPORTS OF UNSAFE OPENINGS:
The Police Department shall report to the Director of Public Works the name and
address of the owner or occupant of any property having a space under the
sidewalk thereof, the cover of which is broken or has a slippery surface.
Thereupon the Director of Public Works shall forthwith notify the owner or
occupant to repair or remove such covering within a specified time and
substitute another that will provide secure footing for pedestrians.
22-6-19: UNSAFE OPENING:
Whenever any vault or space is not covered or secured as provided in this
Article or in the opinion of the Director of Public Works is unsafe or
inconvenient for public travel, such Director may order the same to be placed
in a safe condition satisfactory to him and if the same shall not be done
within ten (10) days after service of written notice on the owner or person in
possession of the premises, the Director may make such change and the expense
thereof shall be paid by such owner in possession of the premises.
22-6-20: RECORDS AND INSPECTION:
The office of the Village Clerk shall keep a complete record of all spaces
underneath the surface of the street or other public ground and from time to
time the Director of Public Works shall make or cause to be made such
inspection of all spaces as may be necessary to determine if the provisions of
this Article are being complied with.
22-6-21: NOTICE BY CODE ENFORCEMENT DIRECTOR OF SUBSURFACE AREAS IN USE OR
INTENDED TO BE USED; NOTIFICATION TO USERS OF PROVISIONS OF THIS ARTICLE:
It shall be the duty of the Director of Code Enforcement to report to the
Director of Public Works the spaces underneath the portions of the sidewalks or
other public places that are being or are intended to be used by any abutting
property owner and each of such property owners shall there after be notified
by the Director of Public Works, of the provisions of this Article.
22-6-22: CERTIFICATE OF SURVEY OF SUBSURFACE AREA, ETC.:
It shall be the duty of every person for whom a space underneath the surface of
the street or public ground may be in process of construction to procure the
same to be measured by a competent surveyor and to deliver to the Director of
Public Works a certificate of such measurement signed by the surveyor before
the arching of such space or cover shall be constructed. The enlargement or
increase in size of any such space shall be construed to be an original new,
independent and separate construction and shall be governed by the provisions
of this Article as in the case of original, new, independent and separate
construction thereof.
ARTICLE 7
OUTDOOR BENCHES
SECTION:
22-7-1: Definitions
22-7-2: Where Prohibited
22-7-3: Permit - Required
22-7-4: Permit - Application
22-7-5: Permit - Liability Insurance Requirements
22-7-6: Permit - Expiration; Fee; Removal
22-7-7: Permit - Grounds for Denial; Cancellation
22-7-8: Permit - Revocation of Permit
22-7-9: Specifications
22-7-10: Display of Permittee's Name and Permit Number
22-7-11: Duties of Permittee
22-7-12: Advertising Prohibited
22-7-13: Installation and Maintenance Supervision
22-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases shall have the meanings, and are hereby
defined, as follows:
BENCH: A seat located upon public property along any public way for the
accommodation of pedestrians.
STREET: Any public thoroughfare or way including the sidewalk, the parkway and
any other public property bordering upon a public way.
22-7-2: WHERE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect a bench within the Village at any
of the following locations:
   A.   In any alley.
   B.   At any location where the distance from the face of the curb to the
property line is less than eight feet (8').
   C.   At a point less than thirty inches (30") from the face of the curb to
the front of the bench; each bench must be kept parallel with the curb.
22-7-3: PERMIT - REQUIRED:
No person shall install or maintain any bench on any street without a permit. A
separate permit must be obtained for each bench, which permit shall be valid
only for the particular location specified thereon. Each permit shall bear a
separate number and not more than two (2) permits shall be issued for any one
location. All said permits shall be issued by the Village Clerk.
22-7-4: PERMIT - APPLICATION:
No bench permit shall be issued except upon written application, made upon a
form prescribed by the Village Clerk, showing the proposed location of each
bench, and such other information as the Director of Public Works may require.
Detailed plans and specifications of each bench shall be supplied by the
applicant.
22-7-5: PERMIT - LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
No permit required by this Article shall be issued unless the applicant shall
post and maintain with the Village Clerk, public liability insurance as
hereinafter provided:
   A.   The policy of insurance shall be conditioned that the permittee will
indemnify and save harmless the Village, its officers and employees from any
and all losses, costs, damages, expenses or liabilities which may result from
or arise out of the granting of the permit, to the installation or maintenance
of the bench for which the permit is issued and that the permittee will pay any
and all loss or damage that may be sustained by any person as a result of, or
which may be caused by or arise out of such installation or maintenance. The
policy of insurance shall be maintained in its original amount by the permittee
at his expense at all times during the period for which the permit is in
effect. In the event that two (2) or more permits are issued to one permittee,
one such policy of insurance may be furnished to cover two (2) or more benches
and each policy shall be of such a type that its coverage shall be
automatically restored immediately from and after the time of the reporting of
any accident from which liability may thereafter accrue. The Village shall be
named as a party insured in said policy.
   B.   The limit of liability upon any policy of insurance posted pursuant to
the requirements of this Article shall in no case be less than one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injuries to one person and two hundred
thousand ($200,000.00) for injuries to more than one person.
22-7-6: PERMIT - EXPIRATION; FEE; REMOVAL:
Each permit issued under this Article shall expire on May 1 next following the
date of issuance unless renewed. A fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each bench
shall be charged annually. Application for renewal must be made prior to the
expiration date, and must be accompanied by the renewal fee.
22-7-7: PERMIT - GROUNDS FOR DENIAL; CANCELLATION:
The application for a permit under the provisions of this Article shall be
denied if the Director of Public Works shall find that the maintenance of the
bench would tend to obstruct passage along any public way or to create a hazard
or would otherwise be detrimental to the public safety, welfare or convenience.
The application for a permit shall be canceled and denied if the applicant
fails to deposit the annual fee and accept the permit within ten (10) days
after notice of the approval of the application by the Director of Public
Works. (1981 Code)
22-7-8: PERMIT; REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
The Director of Public Works may revoke or deny any permit issued under the
provisions of this Article for any violation of any of the provisions of this
Article for any fraud or misrepresentation in the application, or for any
reason which would have been grounds for denial of the application.
Any permit shall be canceled and revoked if the permittee fails to install the
bench within sixty (60) days after the date of the issuance of the permit.
(1981 Code)
22-7-9: SPECIFICATIONS:
No bench installed under the provisions of this Article shall be more than
forty two inches (42") high nor more than two feet six inches (2'6") wide, nor
more than seven feet (7') long overall. The backrest and seat of the bench
shall each be constructed of a minimum of three (3) boards or strips or slats
made from two inch (2") stock and shall each be limited to a maximum width of
seven inches (7") and shall be of equal width in the back and in equal width in
the seat. There shall be a minimum open space between slats of one and one-half
inches (11/2") on the back and one-half inch (1/2") on the seat. (1981 Code)
22-7-10: DISPLAY OF PERMITTEE'S NAME AND PERMIT NUMBER:
Each bench installed under the provisions of this Article must have displayed
thereon, in a conspicuous place, the name of the permittee number. (1981 Code)
22-7-11: DUTIES OF PERMITTEE:
It shall be the duty of any person holding a permit under the provisions of
this Article to maintain each bench at all times in a safe condition and at its
proper and lawful location, and to inspect each bench periodically. (1981 Code)
22-7-12: ADVERTISING PROHIBITED:
No advertising matter or sign whatever shall be displayed upon any bench
installed under the provisions of this Article. (1981 Code)
22-7-13: INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE SUPERVISION:
The Director of Public Works shall supervise the erection and maintenance of
all benches installed under the provisions of this Article. (1981 Code)
ARTICLE 8
STREET NAMES AND HOUSE NUMBERS
SECTION:
22-8-1: Continuation Of Street Names
22-8-2: North-South Base Or Dividing Lines
22-8-3: System Of Numbering
